summary: Officer K (Ryan Gosling), a new blade runner for the Los Angeles Police Department, unearths a long-buried secret that has the potential to plunge what's left of society into chaos. His discovery leads him on a quest to find Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford), a former blade runner who's been missing for 30 years.

One of the most seamless marriages of cinematography, narrative, and GFX. A gorgeously crafted movie that has pioneered the conventions of cinematography accompanied by its immsersive and droning soundscape, thereby successfully reserving its spot in the pantheon of groundbreaking films. The brutalist architecture, overwhelming landscapes that swallow characters, contrasting color palettes like drowning irradiated Los Angelinos in a bright orange hue, these define the film and qualify it as an everlasting experience through a myriad of visual beauty. However, the story is dragged out and can seem overly long, but each shot is masterfully carried out, and that deserves the viewing and praise. I am forever perplexed how this marvel flunked at the box office. Its soundscape and cinematography surely were elevated in the experience.

Set 30 years after the original, ‘Blade Runner 2049' follows LAPD "blade runner" Officer K (Ryan Gosling) as he uncovers a secret that could cause chaos in his dystopian society. At nearly 3 hours long, you're taken on a lengthy investigation to discover the origins of said secret, yet the movie keeps you engaged and interested through its entire runtime. The cast all deliver great performances, specifically Gosling and Jared Leto (who plays, you guessed it, a creepy guy). The stunning scenery and set design fully immerse you in this futuristic world, and the music perfectly complements every scene it's utilized in. This film also has some of the best cinematography I've ever seen, and from a visual standpoint, is truly a work of art. While I'm admittedly not a fan of the original, I enjoyed this sequel much more. A riveting sci-fi mystery (you could even call it a detective story) with some gorgeous camerawork and an unexpected twist or two, ‘Blade Runner 2049' is more than worth your time and will linger in your mind long after the credits roll. 
(Side note: I would recommend watching the original first, as you'll probably understand and enjoy this one more.)

I really enjoyed this movie. I wish I could have seen it sooner, I watched it for the first time 2/11/23. The movie goes through so many highs and lows for our main character while telling a beautifully crafted story. The movie has themes that are eerily similar to what people can experience in real life. Like the feelings of searching for a purpose, truly feeling alone, struggling to know what to believe in, feeling like a slave, being trapped, losing a loved one, and feeling like your life is meaningless. I know a lot of movies can show these emotions and feelings, but the way this movie goes about it is special. I also think this is Ryan Gosling best work I have seen. The way he portrays this character really makes you really feel connected with him and his journey. He also somehow brings this emptiness and sadness that I have never seen in a character. The movie is also a cinematography masterpiece. It has beautiful and breathtaking visuals with equally dark and scary visuals. You really feel like this dystopian future is really not that far fetched and you could be looking at it. I would recommend this movie to anyone who is struggling with trauma or depression. You can really relate to this movie which can help cope with those emotions but it also could be a trigger. This movie does have a heavy emotional impact. I would also recommend this movie to anyone else over 18+. There is some hard concept to grasp and a fair amount of gore, violence, and nudity. After watching this film for the first time I knew it was already one of my favorite films. I would highly recommend giving it a watch.

I can confidently say that Blade Runner 2049 is a triumph of filmmaking. The film dares to be ambiguous, but ambiguity is a good fit with its reflective nature. On its own merits, it is a very strong film; as a sequel, it's nothing short of brilliant.

The performances of Ryan Gosling and Harrison Ford are outstanding and their onscreen chemistry suggests an evolution of masculinity within the films. The world building is immaculate, full of true wonder, and keeps you under its spell all the way to the very end. In some ways, it even surpasses the original.

The story is a methodically structured puzzle, solved through slow but persistent drips of revelation. The director, Denis Villeneuve, achieves a cerebral and even touching picture, while also accomplishing an uncommonly sublime production, marks Blade Runner 2049 as a landmark in the science-fiction genre.

Overall, I highly recommend this film to all hedy science-fiction fans, as it is a new chapter, a triumph, and a cinematic miracle. A must-watch for any cinephile.

Blade Runner 2049 Review
	In Blade Runner 2049 a new Blade Runner who goes by K discovers a secret which leads him to go searching for former Blade Runner Rick Deckard. 
Blade Runner 2049 is like Blade Runner in which it's a futuristic world where it seems like it's night all the time and raining all the time. The protagonist in Blade Runner 2049 Agent K is like the protagonist in Blade Runner Rick Deckard. He gets frustrated a lot because it's difficult for him to solve a puzzle as a cop. The character Luv in Blade Runner 2049 is like the character Roy because she wants to be more human, only she tries to achieve her goal by doing evil. 
The world created in Blade Runner 2049 is fascinating because, like the first Blade Runner it's always night and raining. The director has his own style by making it a world that's snowy and cloudy as well. Most of the action takes place indoors or outdoors of the futuristic world. There's action when the bad guys capture Rick, when Agent K finds him in a city or town. Lighting is used to highlight the action.  For example, an orange lighting is seen when he finds Rick.   It is revealed that for all these years Rick has been spending time in an abandoned casino.
	The casino looks very futuristic and techno like. It shows holograms of Elvis Presley, Frank Sinatra, and Marilyn Monroe. The holograms appear in a place that looks like a bar and another place that looks like a restaurant. The holograms make sounds which is a little disturbing and this happens when K and Rick are fighting.
	Blade Runner 2049 is worth seeing because it's brilliant with its visuals and script.

On many levels, Villeneuve's film is superior to Scott's original. It is more beautiful, better paced, even better acted. I loved it.
And it is more clever. Luv literally crushes K's Joi, a wonderful metaphor: K sacrifices his joy (and his life) to help Deckard meet his daughter (the kind of love K can never experience).
And yet, K's quest is not the equal of Roy Batty's in the original. We are left with a low-stakes reason for watching. K is not Parsifal, and his sacrifice is not understandable other than as a personal gesture. 
Had Villeneuve found a way to elevate rather than diminish K's sacrifice, his film would endure.

Blade Runner 2049 is long and meditative, aiming to immerse the audience in its world and mythos much more than it tries to deliver on audience expectations. That means not every character feels utilized to their full potential, and some plot threads can feel overly long while others were half-baked. But it may also be one of the film's biggest strengths as it decides to owe nothing to anything but itself and its predecessor, resulting in a confident, singular vision. Does that make for a movie everyone flocks to the movie theatre to see? No, and it was the same case for the first film. However, it does end up being easy to love for its target audience, and I expect it to stand the test of time.

Blade Runner 2049 is a movie I recommend to anyone that wants to invest their time watching a good movie. It is not a traditional fast-paced science fiction movie. It is a detective movie, with a slow pace in the first part of it, but also with a jaw-dropping knot and conclusion. I rate it five stars.
The story of the movie is written masterfully. The secret of the naturally born replicant unveils smoothly. As the audience follows Officer K, they learn the different facts about the case. When they reach the end, the parts of the case merge to deliver a plot twist that will leave the audience speechless. The plot of Blade Runner 2049 is story writing at its finest. 
The film will not only entertain the audience, but it will also make them think and feel. More relevant than its story or technical aspects, the strongest quality of the movie is its thought-provoking message. The audience will not only enjoy a great movie, but they will also ponder about their own lives.

Beautiful, melancholy, introspective, and thought provoking. Incredible cinematography, countless scenes in this movie are striking masterpieces of filmography, particularly the car on the beach scene near the end. The movie creates powerful questions that make the viewer question what they define humanity as- what does it mean to be human? In what ways are humans and replicants different? Where do you draw the line? This movie leaves you thinking for days and weeks after. If you haven't read the book "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?" or seen the first movie, you may need to read up on some background after. But I think this movie is enjoyable even without understanding the background. My only regret is that I didn't see the movie in theaters. The only big turnoffs I can point out to potential viewers are the length and the fact the movie is a bit of a slow burn. But if you can handle digging into the depths of your own mind to try to answer the most foundational questions defining humanity, then I can't recommend Blade Runner 2049 enough!

The very essence of Style over Substance. 
Visually gorgeous. Good acting, mostly.  Harrison Ford almost looked like he cared, a couple of times.  But that's all of the plusses. 
The writers were obviously more concerned with being clever, unpredictable, and mysterious than concerned about telling a cohesive story in a movie length situation.

From the almost complete lack of an identifiable antagonist (Leto's cartoonish character? Luv? Who is the antagonist that drives the conflict with the protagonist that provides narrative push? No one.), a protagonist that ends up not mattering one whit, a silly "plot twist/shocking reveal" focused story that significantly reduces any re-watchability, a relationship story in Joi and K that's just zeroed out suddenly in such a way that clearly demonstrates that it wasn't very important (yet somehow took up a vast amount of screen time early in the film), a soundtrack that was perfectly OK Hans Zimmer but had only one recognizable song, one moment where the audience felt it and THAT one part was from the original movie's Vangelis soundtrack. People certainly won't be listening to this generic Zimmer score 30 years from now like they still listen to Vangelis original Blade Runner soundtrack.

And the additional frustration of being told "you just don't get it" and "oh, you're part of the attention deficit audience problem".  No, I got it fine, it's not exactly Fellini. It's just poorly written.

The day before yesterday, I watched one of the most acclaimed and philosophical sci-fi movies of all time: "Blade Runner". 35 years later, Denis Villeneuve (Ridley Scott this time was executive producer only) directed a sequel that gets two rare achievements: first, it maintains the original's essence, expands its universe, and the protagonist is as charismatic as Rick Deckard and it's not swallowed by him when both are on screen; and second, IT SURPASSES THE ORIGINAL! If the 1982 film was philosophical, this one is PHILOSOPHICAL with capital letters and maybe bold. While in that film we followed a journey of self-discovery of a supporting character, here we follow the protagonist's journey of self-discovery; he's actually solving two cases: the case that the LAPD assigned him (the external one) and the subsequent case that a piece of evidence put on his "mind" (the internal one). 30 years have been passed, it was incredible to see how the world has evolved and how the replicants have evolved; the dynamic between humans and replicants are completely different now, which impeded the screenwriters (the same of the 1982 film) to tell the same type of story. It's still an action/sci-fi movie, but they knew what made "Blade Runner" so special and invested in that sector. Ryan Gosling is perfect as K: inexpressive on the outside (he's a replicant after all), but as the film progresses, his emotions start to be de-bottled. Harrison Ford is a legendary actor and Rick Deckard is possibly his third most famous character, only behind Han Solo and Indiana Jones; Deckard's cold personality is maintained here, and Gosling proved how good he is by not being obfuscated by Ford's presence. Ana de Armas' character is by far the most intriguing: she, in personality, looks like Karen (Plankton's computer wife from "SpongeBob: SquarePants") but with a human body, and she's possibly the pivot of K's internal journey (alongside Mackenzie Davis). Dave Bautista and Jared Leto have little screen time but their characters aren't forgettable, Sylvia Hoeks is a cool and dangerous antagonist, and Robin Wright remembered me of Judi Dench's M from Daniel Craig's 007 franchise. The cinematography, soundtrack and sound work are DAZZLING; this movie is definitely a sensory experience, and I'm really jealous of those who watched this masterpiece in a movie theatre. Oh, and I still keep with my theory that Rick Deckard is a human.

In 2017, I was looking forward to seeing this movie hit the big screen. For whatever reason, I never got around to going out and seeing it - this was a major mistake. It would eventually hit Red Box and my wife and I checked it out. I was distracted while I watched it and didn't pay too much attention to the movie - this was a major mistake. Early in 2020, I decided to sit down and just watch the movie again by myself - this was a great decision! Dennis Villeneuve and Roger Deakins along with the superb cast, crew, and production team really did create a masterpiece here that deserves your undivided attention from start to finish. What's more, Hans Zimmer captured the atmosphere of the original Blade Runner film with his soundtrack, while creating something entirely new. I've probably watched this movie 30-40 times since 2020 and I have to apologize to Dennis for not seeing the movie in theaters as it was intended - I saw Dune twice to make up for it!!

This surely had the best cinematography of any movie I've seen, driven at least partially by the production design giving Deakins such aesthetically pleasing things to point his camera at. The mix of awe, appreciation and recognition that I was witnessing pure cinematic art is difficult to put into words. This franchise has by far the most intriguing backdrop of any movie I've ever seen and watching more plots unfold in it will be a joy if they go forward with their TV show or more movies. I feel especially sure of that because of how uninteresting I found this particular plot to be, a similar feeling I had to the first one. The incredible sense of magnitude and hidden depths and mystery that their impeccable setting offers led me to appreciate even less how ultra-low the plot's stakes were. I didn't agree that killing the replicants was necessary in the first place (at least in the context of the movie; I'm aware the novel is different) and tracking down the kid was just not a riveting premise for me. My opinion was reduced even further when they directly tied Deckard into it instead of just having him show up to help as it implies that in all of the gigantic cityscape the only two interesting things to have ever happened involved him. As with the first movie I feel I would appreciate this (which essentially serves as a requel) more if it began a franchise where better stories are told in the same universe.

A sequel as visually dazzling and thought-provoking as the original, this film truly stands as a momentous achievement in its own right. Firstly, Roger Deakins was very much deserving of the Oscar he won for cinematography. Each shot is museum worthy. And Villeneuve and the rest of the creative team brought to life again this dystopic vision of a cyberpunk future LA, and it remains enchanting. I also love the route they take with this story, centering on a Blade Runner who knows he is a replicant instead of rehashing the is-he-or-isn't-he question of Deckard from the first one. K's arc of slowly starting to believe that he is special only to find out that, in that one specific way, he is not was satisfyingly subversive. The parallelism of Luv, a replicant who also sees herself as special, is a great choice as well. Joi is another character that invites analysis, since we have to consider (as K does) if she was merely following her obvious AI programming to make K feel better or if she was able to reach some level of being a "real girl." As with the original, it is a slow movie that really demands your attention. And as with the original, I feel this is a film that requires multiple viewings to truly have seen it. Blade Runner 2049 (2017) directed by Denis Villeneuve.

Thirty years after the events of Blade Runner (1982), a new blade runner, Oficcer K ( Ryan Gosling) discovers one big secret about the replicants that could turn the world around and cause a revolution. His discovery leads him to find more about the truth and ends up finding Rick Deckard, a L.A.P.D. officer, who has been missing for 30 years.

Denis Villeneuve is a Sci-Fi master and was able to put together an incredible piece of art. With the help of one of the best cinematographers working right now, the incredible Roger Deakins, and the help of the amazing Han Zimmer, Denis was able to present us with this Masterpiece.

This movie is everything a sequel should be it picks up the universe it's predecessor created and expanded it and somehow also made it more interesting. It created great new characters, which we were able to connect with, and was able to bring elements from the past with sublteness and intelligence.

It takes it's time and it's the opposite of the majority of the modern Sci-Fi movies. Its pace paired with the astounishing shots and the groundbreaking score allows us to connect with everything in this universe, it captures us and makes us prisioners of that world for the runtime of 2 hours and 44 minutes.

The story unrolls in quite an unique way, it's like every inch of dialogue matters and you really don't want to miss anything, just for the pleasure of connecting the dots and being able to feel everything. I wasn't expecting to be hit in such an emotional level.

Ryan Gosling was definitly the best casting choice. He absolutely nailed the role. Ana de Armas was also amazing and portrayed the role of the A.I. Cyberpunk girlfriend with ease. Harisson as always was a fucking badass. Carla Juri with little screentime was able to do a really great job portraying Rachael and Rick's long lost daughter.

This is one of the most beautifully shot movies I've seen, every look, every landscape, every face, every shot felt like it should be there and carried a lot with it. Loneliness and the sense of getting lost have never been so well portrayed in a Sci-Fi movie.

This is everything modern Sci-Fi movies should be.

Thank you Denis for making this Masterpiece, thank you Ridley for creating this world. Would give everything to be able to watch this on the big screen.

Bladerunner or Bladebummer?

I really wanted to enjoy this film, I was even looking forward to
something a bit more mainstream after our obscurities, but one must be
careful what one wishes for and in the end I couldn't, it was just too
American.

All the mood lighting, bizarre decor and weird noises - just didn't work
for me. Although Scott's film had these in his it served to create a
believable, if alien, and atmospheric world. In this one it just served
to give the appearance of trying to convince idiotic Americans that
something significant or profound was going on. If an intelligent man
said they found this stylisation an original and artistic creation I
would believe him but for me, it was not that.

The characters too were often paper thin - the protagonist, with
designer stubble and bomber jacket come trenchcoat, being played as hard
boiled when he was obviously the prettiest boy in school, the hard
hitting ageing blond tom boy boss with greased back hair who swore a lot
and acted mean but in the end died for her employee, the sexy but deadly
evil assassin in tight trousers, the weird psycho in some bizarre
futuristic version of a lonely mansion having no idea what a fruitloop
he is whilst seemingly performing some of the world's most complex
scientific tasks with nothing more than a giant plastic bag, some slime
and a floating camera for tools - all a little bit cliche for me.

The dialogue didn't do any better which at it's absolute best was
sickeningly pseudo-philosophical with fake insight and dubious value.

That being said I did start to warm to the film a little, or perhaps
just got used to it, then they brought in Harry. It felt a little like
Luke Skywalker in the new Star Wars - these youngsters, actors and
directors, need to bring in the old hands to give what they are doing
some depth, what are they going to do when there are no more old hands?
But Harry did bring a little depth, but not enough and he could not
redeem the film.

The whole thing seemed like something that was created deliberately to
make money or make an impression but there seemed very little
originality or creativity in it, like a man making an unusual looking
cake but underneath is just a sponge to a tried and tested recipe, it
did not feel like an artist's individual and personal expression.
Perhaps it is the cinema version of contemporary art - pointless.

Blade Runner 2049 is a sequel that goes toe to toe with the original Blade Runner in terms of riveting visuals, atmosphere and memorable dialogue. The makers were wise enough to make the movie its own in terms of design and pacing, use sound and music in a creative way to hark back to the original and use CGI in a restrained and an unobtrusive way. Although the pacing is not as tight as the original the writing is not afraid to push this futuristic story into uncharted and disturbing territories. Like the original story the police are hunting synthetic humanoids, but with a plot twist- synthetic humans are killed if they are outdated in favor of newer more obedient models. The Blade Runner hunting the synthetic humans is himself a stronger, more resilient, more lethal and more observant synthetic human. All of this takes place in a dystopian view of the future where the cities are gray sprawling overpopulated over-polluted industrial wastelands devoid of any beauty. A new corporation has arisen producing ever more efficient and obedient synthetic humans headed by a creative industrialist. Given that the newer and more obedient synthetic humans are even more efficient killing machines than before the movie suggests in no uncertain terms that the fault lies eternally with humanity as a savage and immoral maker and not the creation. The main character in the movie, the synthetic human Blade Runner ‘K' also has a holographic female companion. The notion that artificial life will seek companionship from other artificial life forms seems strangely unsettling, as if it requires some sort of supervision or that the need for companionship is a unique trait restricted to humans. The need for a machine to have need for companionship also makes it appear as a drawback revealing an interesting assumption that we view machines as supposedly efficient, but not ourselves as machines or at least accept that we are ‘inefficient machines'. Whereas the original Blade Runner raised philosophical questions Blade Runner 2049 makes our transgressions and prejudices visceral and pushes them right in front of the audience.  Whether it is the slimy birth of a new synthetic model, children working in factories, intolerance for artificial life procreating or the dismissal of the illusion of free will underpinned by genetics, the movie doesn't pull punches. In his search for the offspring of Replicants the Blade Runner ‘K' navigates a hellscape of industrial excrement, but the most damning indictment is that humanity ultimately gave up on the real world and morality and lives in the ruins of past efforts to produce more and more tactile fantasies.

Short review: blade runner 2049 is a stunningly shot, well acted, and wonderfully complex film that wholeheartedly lives up to the original 
long review: Blade runner 2049 follows "k" (Ryan Gosling) a new age replicant who is tasked with hunting down and "retiring" older model replicant who have been deemed  illegal. but clues lead him to believe that he may be more than just a replicant... truthfully that is only about a quarter of the plot, but revealing any more would spoil the movie. watching this movie was a treat the whole way through. all the actors played their parts beautifully, especially Ryan Gosling and Ana de Armas. but possibly the best part of the about this movie is the cinematography. every shot is beautiful on its own, and when they are put together it becomes one of the most stunning movies that i have watched in a long time. another aspect of this film that i loved was the complex plot of the movie that only fits together at the very end. although this could confuse some of the less attentive viewers, it rewards everyone who pays attention to the screen. the plot is also incredibly character driven, which allows the almost every character in the movie to have a well thought out and detailed ark. that being said there was a couple small things i didn't care for as much. for example  there are 2 or 3 moments where a character has a realization and the movie flashes back to a previous scene. this slightly removed me from the immersion of the film. however, this is a small complaint about what is otherwise an incredible film.

Blade Runner 2049 is honestly a masterpiece and a half, the movie's got a great story.

The story is pretty much about this lad called Officer K (Ryan Gosling) who's an officer with the Los Angeles police department, he finds out a big secret which could end up starting lots of chaos.

He later goes on a mission to find a former blade runner called Deckard (Harrison Ford) who's been missing for the past three decades.

The acting from all of the cast throughout this movie is honestly brilliant, especially from Ryan Gosling and Harrison Ford, those two are honestly amazing in this movie.

The dialogue which is given throughout this movie is honestly brilliant, the dialogue never feels too forced. It just feels very natural and it's really well given from all of the characters who are in this movie.

Also, the chemistry between Officer K and Deckard is great and it's built up so well throughout this movie.

The movie's even got some beautiful music composed by Hans Zimmer, Benjamin Wallfisch, Ron Bartlett and Michael Hodges. Those four do a great job on composing this beautiful soundtrack as a whole.

The pacing throughout this movie is honestly great and each moment is built up very well.

The cinematography from the man, the myth and the legend Roger Deakins is honestly so beautiful. He captures the scenes so beautifully and he does such a great job at capturing the moments so well.

The CGI effects hold up pretty well and they don't look very outdated at all, which is really good.

The green screen effects throughout this movie also hold up very well and they're very aesthetically pleasing to look at.

The movie's even got some great visuals which also hold up very well and they have such a unique look to them.

The set designs for this movie have a very beautiful and unique look to them, which I thought made them look very unique.

Overall, Blade Runner 2049 is honestly a masterpiece and a half. The movie's got a great story, brilliant acting, brilliant dialogue, great chemistry, beautiful score, great pacing and some beautiful cinematography.

The movie's even got some very graphic action sequences, great CGI effects, aesthetically pleasing greenscreen effects, great visuals and some very beautiful set designs.

What kind of sci-fi film would Jesus make? We'll leave that to the Thumpers and the Trumpsters, but maybe this one is to the New Testament as the original "Blade Runner" is to Genesis—though the latter remains the undisputed masterpiece. BR2049 is thoroughbred Blade Runner, though, seamlessly flowing from its progenitor to expand the narrative to deeper, richer and visually stunning themes and a moodier melancholy. The retrofitted future comes with updates: what more could a lonely Blade Runner want than a beautiful sentient holographic wife who can sync with real prostitutes? The rainy city's streets are still dominated by everything Japanese (although Ryan Gosling's anti-gravity car is a Peugeot, of all things). But more to the point: like a leisurely swim in a warm pool, you'll find yourself luxuriating in philosophical and sociopolitical themes of corporate Big Brother, life and death, existential angst, what's real and what's not. Do androids dream of electric sheep?

If the original film had any loose ends (which is debatable), they flap about for three hours here, until assuming their final positions with some well judged twists along the way. And don't get me wrong, the twists are good.

But we don't watch Blade Runner for twists; we want a surprising future to reveal itself, and as a sequel it can't play that card again. It becomes more about memory than ever: memories of memories (such as the holograms of his lost love or of Elvis); memories of other people's memories (driving the characters); and our own memory of the first film.

Because of this reference to our own memories, the film is somewhat stuck to its prequel, and though this involves us intimately, it's not always in a good way. It breaks the fourth wall by constantly reminding us that we're watching a movie.

Here we also see the phenomenon of how sequels are strait jacketed by the premises set down in the original. This always risks a slight block to creativity, and belabouring once fresh ideas, and worst of all, narrows the corridors and shrinks the maze in which the writers can roam.

If the majestic pace of the original was supported by Vangelis's heavy score, this one drags somewhat with less air in the musical balloon to haul it along. Not one theme is memorable, and the whole score sounds like a bad pastiche.

Suffused with yellow light and wonderful performances, there is gold to be found here, literally, but nowhere near the treasure of the original.

Thirty years after the events of the first movie, Blade Runner 2049 follows the story of replicant K (Ryan Gosling) who unearths a secret that could rock the world to its core. I remember watching this for the first time and scoring it high 90's. While I still think it's a damn good movie, I feel it falls just out of Masterpiece range.

Acting: 10
Gosling was stellar in his performance as K. Replicants walk the line of being human, but robotic at the same time. In some cases Gosling provides responses that are straight out of the mouth of a program while there are some scenes that require him to capture raw emotion, both unexpected and welcomed by me as a viewer. There were some other memorable performances as well, particularly by Sylvia Hoeks in her role as Luv. I'll be honest, she frightened the hell out of me, but in a good way. She was calculated and controlled, but you could always sense a rage waiting to surface. I love what she did with this character.

Beginning: 10
The opening scene of this movie sees K tracking down a replicant that's been trying to fly under the radar. The tension is built slowly before it bubbles over. In the climax of this scene, we get a taste of what is to come for the rest of the movie. That's what beginnings are all about: Leave us wanting more!

Characters: 10

Cinematography/Visuals: 10
While the entire film as a whole may not qualify as a masterpiece, the visuals and cinematography most certainly are. Throughout the movie, you get a chique futuristic feel that's also dreary and dank at the same time. It's like you're watching two worlds collide. I love their play on robotics and weaponry here as well, definitely a step up from the first film.

Conflict: 10
It's not just about the action here, but also K unravelling a mystery before our eyes. You want him to get to the bottom of everything going on and you're taken on a wild ride along the way. Between the shootouts with hi-tech guns and the hand-to-hand fights, there is more than enough to keep you entertained. 

My favorite scene in particular occurs when K and Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) meet for the first time and square off. They are in some kind of concert hall where holograms are performing. Both are relying on the singing of the holograms to improve their striking position. It really is fun to watch.

Entertainment Value: 9
It doesn't take you long into this movie to realize you're watching something special. The time and energy that went into the creation of this movie shows up on screen. Yes, it could have been shortened, but I still had a great experience.

Memorability: 10
There is a scene that sticks out in my head where replicant creator Niander Wallace (Jared Leto) is looking over one of his creations. It's unsettling to put it lightly and you feel like it's just an average monologue…until it's not. There are a number of scenes just like this that press on my brain. I also loved the continued exploration from the last movie of what it means to be human.

Pace: 8
I do appreciate that the story took its time to unfold. However, I do feel like it could have been a smidge faster in spots. There were a few moments where I was thinking, "Man, I got things to do! Let's go!" Mostly forgivable save for a few instances.

Plot: 10

Resolution: 1
Without giving anything away, I will just say that this is my least favorite part of the movie. To have started so strong only to end like this? Not impressed. I wanted more for K is all I will say.

Overall: 88
There's nothing like good sci-fi when done well. Blade Runner 2049 will take you on highs and lows while giving you a visual feast in the process. I was not disappointed in the least and you won't be either.

This is what sci-fi is all about. There are so many layers to this beautifully rendered masterpiece that it begs re-watching almost immediately. The film falls into none of the traps other sci-fi sequels do and when the character of Deckard is reintroduced Harrison totally re-creates a seamless performance from the first installment. All other performances are first class and worthy of a place in sci-fi history.

Denis Villeneuve had a near impossible task in producing a worthy sequel to one of the greatest films of all time Blade Runner (1982) and miraculously he does. Despite casting Ryan Gosling, the Harrison Ford of his day, in the lead when he could have picked a more interesting character screenwriters Hampton Fancher and Michael Green populate the film with fascinating characters like Luv and Niander Wallace. The film is almost as beautiful as it's predecessor and contains action scenes that equal the pursuit of Zhora while continuing the exploration of the philosophical questions asked in the first film. I had high expectations going in and I was on cloud nine for the rest of the week having had all of my expectations met.

Thirty years after the events of Blade Runner, â~blade runner' K, Ryan Gosling, discovers that replicants can sexually reproduce and is told by his commanding officer lieutenant Joshi, Robin Wright, to retire the offspring of Rachael. Meanwhile, Niander Wallace, Jared Leto, the successor to Tyrell sends replicant Luv, Sylvia Hoeks, to steal the remains of Rachael, the replicant who reproduced, so that he can use them for his own nefarious means. K, a replicant himself, comes to believe that he is Rachael's child when his memories match up to information he finds. As in the first film, there is a climactic showdown between hero and villain where the lines become blurred and philosophical questions are pondered.

By far the best aspect of the film is the exploration of Luv's character because she is the most emotionally affecting in the film. Her desire to her prove herself to her near psychopathic father Niander is never more clear than at the moment at which the body of a fellow replicant is carelessly disposed of as we see a single tear trickle down her otherwise placid face. Her physical abilities are also impressive as she is able to match K in their final fight and when she confidently states "I am the best one" I felt the sort of excitement I have only ever felt at the end of Krzysztof Kieslowski movies. She was emotionally complex and it was fun to watch her fight the male lead, what more could you want from the female lead in a Blade Runner sequel?

Although I would not consider Harrison Ford to be a great actor and I felt the lack of development in the relationship between Rachael and Deckard was one of the few flaws of the first film their relationship produced one of the most emotional moments in the film. When Deckard stares at a hologram of Rachael and is tested on his response he responds tearfully "I know what I felt" as he recognizes that the hologram can not replicate the feelings he had for the Rachael he knew. Ford is surprisingly able to sell the seen as we see a man who cemented himself as a gruff action star give himself over to the emotion of love as the awe in his eyes as the woman he loves touches him again is beautiful and touching. Had Blade Runner dealt with the love story better this scene would have been even more affecting but this scene does a great job at making up time on the predecessor's poor treatment of Rachael and forces you to care.

Of the many, many wonderful things about this film the cinematography is obviously high up on the list as Roger Deakins, returning from the first film, does some of his best work. There is the beautiful orange sheen present in most Deakins film present here but even more so as the Wallace corporation complex is absurdly colorized and reflections of flowing water appear on the walls. Each shot could be framed and put up on my wall, even those of Harrison Ford's confused face, with the exterior shots in particular feeling like worthy successors to the iconic Coca-Cola commercials of the first film.

The year is 2049, there is the real world and the outer world, separated by a wall, presumably built by America and paid for by Mexico. Global warming has not been kind; LA is in the year of winter powered by the perpetually sunny state of California which has been covered in stunning solar panel towers. There is a shortage of crops but we still have cigarettes as tobacco fields are both an important part of American GDP and a great way to make someone look bad ass in the movies.

If this film is in any way a prediction of the future it's good to know that technology gets way out of hand, also buy Mitsubishi shares now, diversify portfolio with Coca-Cola and sex bots.

On a side note I once read that after Return Of The Jedi, George Lucas held back on making any more Star Wars movies until the technology was right. That might also be fitting of Blade Runner. The film just can't fail to disappoint, visually it's stunning, with its vast landscapes, baron city ruins, fallout zones, mega cities, and technological fantasy.

Blade Runner also captures a complex and obscure dystopian future featuring child slavery, android servitude, and a macho world of sexual obscenity not too dissimilar to Duke Nukem's Land Of The Babes. Technologically there is a lot to take in, from the delights of hover cars to mainstream JOI companionship, in 2049 Joi is a robot hologram who will risk everything in the pursuit of syphilis. One bit of technology that stood out was the 4D TV's, I mention as Back To The Future also predicted them so I'm thinking it's only a matter of time folks.

The plot is enjoyable, it neatly works on its predecessor's mind melt that people can't guarantee that they're human because memories are implanted faster than the NSA can access your webcam but it adds a twist with Replicants urging to be recognised as equals, and you get the sense that the Replicants are gearing up for a Hunger Games style conflict sooner or later.

The Replicant's call to war comes with the discovery of a child born of Replicant descent. So basically this is the plot from Orphan Black, a child born from a clone gets hunted down by an evil corporation so that they can do testing on its genetic structure or something.

However unlike Orphan Black there is less logic behind the corporations motivations to recover the child, for instance if they really wanted to produce well behaved drones then reproduction might not be the best way of doing it, on the premise that you have more genetic uncertainties and less control over production and data analysis.  Also it seems as if Mr Wallace has created a technology which has garnered him huge wealth and he's left looking a bit like a one dimensional super villain suffering from a god complex, with very weak motivations and a lack of depth. 

Ms Luv also fails to use the company's firepower to wipe out K which makes it feel a bit like a weak Bond movie at times because you never feel like he is in critical danger and the one question you come away with is why at any point in this movie wasn't K killed when he could have been.

The LAPD leader is like the love child of Theresa May and Mariano Rajoy and her motivations to quell rebellion before it kicks off a referendum are a bit easier to understand. This makes the plot a bit more tangible and if the corporations motivations were a bit meatier this film would have a more complete feel about it.

Blade Runner also attempts to raise familiar questions in AI SciFi such as when is an android considered equal to a human, when does AI start to think for itself, can AI feel real emotion and if so does such emotion relate to independent thought. With that in mind, despite the weak plot points, Blade Runner offers total escapism into a bizarre world, worth seeing for the innovative technologies, abstract ideas and stunning landscapes.

K (Ryan Gosling) is a complex and interesting character. By revealing K to be a Replicant immediately, the film is able to explore the deeper nuances of what it truly means to be human. There is nothing as natural than for movies to spawn sequels. As inevitably as cats have kittens, successful movies will have one or more sequels. In typical fashion the adage, 'strike while the iron is hot,' is applicable. The follow-up movie will usually be released while the initial buzz created by the original is still in effect, usually within two to five years. Lately, several immensely popular action franchises have been reignited even though the principal actor were returning after a couple of decades absence. It remains a significant discrepancy between men and women in Hollywood, but the shelf-life of action heroes has been greatly extended. Last year one of the most controversial, enigmatic cult science fictions received a sequel, 'Blade Runner.' The original film, 'Blade Runner' was a loose adaptation of the 1968 novel Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep? By Philip K. Dick, released in 1982. That film rose to a level beyond a mere cult classic, through the highest echelon of Sci-Fi fandom to a zeitgeist-defining cultural phenomenon. It is far from unusual for a major studio movie to have numerous versions, sifted through and re-edited by the filmmaker to achieve the final product. Elaborate DVD and Blu-ray sets released becoming cherished collector's items. 'Blade Runner' has enjoyed this venerated status for decades, and with the conclusion open to interpretation, many fans have hoped for a sequel. It took longer than most believed possible but thirty-five years that immortal monologue atop the Bradbury Building, 'Blade Runner 2049' has arrived. Set in 'real time.' i.e., thirty-five years after the original fans rejoiced when it was announced that Harrison Ford would reprise his role joined by one of the most popular actors of his generation, Ryan Remolds. Not only has this near-mythical film been made but the cast is ideal.

One of the goals for the film set by director Denis Villeneuve was to venture beyond extending the dystopic Blade runner universe to expand it. The visual impact made by the original change the way the future was depicted. The streets were crowded, rain seems to be constant and the looming buildings festooned with gaudy, animated billboard advertisement. The opening shot of this film depicts a car, on autopilot as its occupant, K (Ryan Gosling), waking from a nap. The wide-open vista of this scene contrasted with the start of the original tells volumes without needing dialogue. Although the landscape is bright with the palette sliding from blues to orange, the overall feel remains desolate, bordering on despair. K is a Blade Runner whose mission is to retire outdated or rogue replicants. There was a long-standing debate as to whether Decker (Harrison Ford), was a replicant himself. K is unmistakably one of the advanced models. The distain displayed by his fellow officers calling him the ultimate pejorative for a replicant, skin job. A crucial piece of exposition is provided when K confronts his target. The replicant slated for retirement is one of the last of the old Nexus models. Before returning to headquarters. He found a box containing the remains of a female replicant who died during an emergency cesarean section. Against their design specifications, replication has somehow obtained the ability to reproduce sexually. When K reports his findings to his supervisor, Lieutenant Joshi (Robin Wright), who is concerned that if this fact became general knowledge, it would result in a panic that would result in the war pitting humans against replicants. Joshi orders K to locate and retire the child replicant. K's first destination is the Wallace Corporation, the successor to the inventor of the technology that replicants feasible, the now-defunct Tyrell Corporation, for help in identifying the maternal replicant. Through a thorough analysis of the DNA, it is determining that the sample belonged to an advanced model replicant known as Rachael (Sean Young). She was the seductively beautiful replicant who became involved with the original old school Blade Runner, Rick Deckard. Playing into the perennial favorite plot motivation, corporate greed is naturally infused as Wallace CEO Neander Wallace (Jared Leto) wants to discover the secret to replicant reproduction placing market share, profits and technological monopoly above any concern for the safety of humanity.

K has a holographic girlfriend, Joi (Ana de Armas), who is formed using a projector on a free moving armature mounted on the ceiling. Besides basic companionship, Joi is capable of synthesizing rather substantial insight. When K discusses seeing a date '6-10-21' carved in the trunk of a tree, he recognizes it as a childhood memory. In talking to Joi, he realizes that since replicant memories are artificial, Joi suggests he might have been born. This exploits a narrative device of plot convergence. The idea of replicant reproduction careering towards the origin story of the principal protagonist. This ignites K's curiosity motivating his search of the LAPD leading to the discovery an unusual set of twins born on that date. K's investigation has the added benefit of providing details about the process used to manufacture replications. Crucial to the process is the creation of the artificial memories, fans always knew the existed, but now the audience is introduced to Dr. Ana Stelline (Carla Juri), a designer of replicant memories. There is no sense of contrivance as this new information seamlessly infused crafting a film that is satisfying to the most diehard fan of the original.

To be fully accepted by the fans a sequel is required to receive some indication that the new installment is 'blessed' confirming its status as canon. The fan could never accept this movie if Harrison Ford were not included in the primary cast the project would have been dead on arrival. This applies in general but after returning to his signature role, Indiana Jones and Hans Solo, after a considerable amount of time. His presence validates the movie permitting it to create its narrative. Instead of immediate dismissal 'Blade Rubber 22049' is the movie fans have been anticipating for thirty-five years. The theme of the story was unencumbered these ancillary concerns. Expanding some of the psychosocial questions raised by Philip K. Dick in his novel, 'Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?' the question under consideration is among the most ancient, what does it mean to be human? The defining qualities of humanity have been pounded by religions, philosophers, and storytellers since people first gathered around a fire at night questioning the unknowable fabric of nature. This has been one of the most popular topics in science fiction often viewed through the prism of robots and later androids. With the growing concerns over the singularity, public attention has intensified. Over the intervening thirty-five years, sentient artificial beings have gone from our conjecture to the realm of possibility. This was the perfect time for this film. Pragmatically, Mr. Ford is 75 years old and plans to extend too far in the future would not be feasible. From a narrative perspective, the singularity is a hot topic, the subject of intense sustaining in the hallow halls of academia in disciplines encompassing quantum physics, computer science, and sociology. Having the replicants gain the ability to autonomously reproduce an intrinsic quality necessary to define life, at the lowest possible level.

As a bonus surprise, Edward James Olmos reprises his role as the enigmatic Gaff. Over the years Mr. Olmos has grown from a highly sought-after journeyman character to an A-List artist capable of incredibly nuanced performances. Addition of an actor of this caliber helps in providing the gravitas to the film necessary of rising to the intricacies inherent in the themes, so many sequels, particularly those overly delayed, are little more than the studio executives seeking to pad the year-end profit report. There is a literary impetus behind the creation of this movie, a genuine need to return to the story that has been with many of us for most of our adult lives. As with any worthy discussion of depth and meaning, this portion of the story raised more question than an answer. It should give the next generation something of substance to consider.

"Yo, I have this idea for a movie."
"Let's hear it."
"Liam Neeson is this badass vigilante who saves passengers on a train from a bad person."
"Cool! Let's do it."
I groaned when word first leaked of another Blade Runner. How dare they mess with Ridley Scott's 1982, science fiction classic! Then, I learned it was a continuation of the original narrative helmed by Denis Villeneuve (Arrival, Sicario, Prisoners) with Ryan Gosling, Jared Leto and Harrison Ford returning as Rick Deckard. I was sold.
Less than a minute into this modern masterpiece, I knew I was watching movie of the year. The futuristic cityscapes are a visionary wonderland to behold. Gosling turns in a commanding performance as a Blade Runner named K, a young detective tasked with retiring older model replicants, artificially-engineered humans created by a mega corporation. When K unearths a mystery that could send his world into chaos, he must find the legendary Blade Runner who can provide the answers.
Villeneuve is a dexterous, provocative filmmaker who seems incapable of producing work without wow factor. This sequel of sorts deserved the box office haul The Last Jedi and Beauty and the Beast achieved but faltered as a projected cash cow. Too many made the mistake of disregarding this flick in theaters. Blade Runner: 2049 stands with Scott's original as timeless, quintessential science fiction, the kind you can't afford to miss.

Writing aside, the cast is brilliant, with Harrison Ford stealing the show as Deckard and having great chemistry with Ryan Gosling's Agent K. However, the films greatest strength is in its visuals. Credits to cinematographer Roger Deakins, every shot of 2049 is beautiful and this continues to be true in its intense, brutal action sequences. Overall, Blade Runner 2049 pays tribute to its predecessor but also builds on the world that it created, through stunning visuals and a provocative question to think of after the film. Its 3-hour runtime can be daunting but (for the most part) the films depth and sheer energy compensate.

Engrossing, beautiful, layered, meticulous, and made with so much soul that I honestly cannot understand how ANYONE could not enjoy these films. 
In my humble opinion, I consider this sequel to Ridley Scott's classic Blade Runner to be a superior picture on nearly every level. Scott's original was a visual feast & featured terrific performances from everyone involved, particularly Harrison Ford, Rutger Hauer, Sean Young and Darryl Hannah. Here, the performances are just as powerful. Ryan Gosling is excellent in the leading role as Officer K, quiet, professionsl, duty bound but also curious and full of heart and when Ford finally appears  (long after half of the film has already played out ) he turns in another stellar performance as a weary, worn out Rick Deckard, 30 something years older but still full of fight. However, the scene stealers, the two standout performances belong  to two relatively unknown young actressss, Ana Dr Armas as Joi, Officer K's holographic girlfriend who genuinely seems capable of love, loyalty, and humanity and Sylvia Hoeks, as the ironically named Luv, a synthetic psycho killing machine custom made by Niander Wallace, an egomaniacal gazillionaire obsessed with creating the most human synthetic possible. Hoeks' performance as Luv is chilling; she is the perfect killing machine, loyal to Wallace but still independent enough to enjoy her work and to.go above and beyond her duty. She steals the show whenever she is on screen and is an excellent villain and formidable opponent to both K and Deckard.  

BR  2049 can be (and is in many ways) a great standalone film  although to really appreciate it, you should be familiar with the original film, as there are tie-ins to it that you won't fully appreciate without having seen Blade Runner. In fact, the plot revolves around Deckard and Rachel (Sean Young's sexy synthetic from the first film who is not in this one, although old imagery of her is used to great effecf) and a child that they may or may not have had. Gosling'a obedient and result oriented K is tasked with finding this possible child and so is Wallace's ruthless, cold and methodical soldier Luv (a female variation of Michael Fassbenders's psychotic synthetic David from Ridley Scott's Prometheus & Alien Covenant films). And Ford's aging Deckard is caught in the middle of this battle.

BR 2049 is a very long, meticulously paced film, at least one full hour longer than the original. Die hard fans of Blade Runner may cry foul and complain about the plot of this entry and it's epic pacing but I, for one thought if was a brilliantly conceived idea; not simply a rehash of the original but something fresh and intelligent. Yes, it is long (very near the 3 hour mark) but I didn't mind and never once was I bored and not once did I think to myself "wow, what a long movie" I was spellbound and so intrigued by the film that I wouldn't have cared if it had went on for another hour. This is entertainment of the highest calibur. Visually masterful, unbelievably vivid, solidly paced, with moments of stunning beauty interspersed with moments of sudden brutal violence. More than all of thar, it is thought provoking; an intriguing parable of what it means to be human. What is worth living, fighting, and dying for.  What it means to have a purpose, human or otherwise. K has to figure this out for himself; and he does in the end, after a nail biting climactic showdown.

Ridley Scott's 1982 film Blade Runner is one of the greatest science fiction movies ever made. Not only was is beautiful to look at, but the broader questions about what makes us human are still used in film today. We didn't need a sequel. No one wanted a sequel. The original, despite its influence, had only ever reached cult status, and indeed wasn't anywhere near a commercial success. There was no real evidence to suggest that a second installment would be financially successful, either.  Blade Runner 2049, really shouldn't have been made, but Denis Villeneuve demanded to tackle the task because he didn't "want anyone else to fuck it up". Somehow he made an epic visual masterpiece that not only gave reverence to its predecessor but also stands on its own and builds on the mythology created before it. It addresses all of the questions, but without ever answering them, because to have the answers would cheapen the experience for both films. The movie also works as a self-contained story. Having seen the original will inform you a bit about the characters, but it isn't necessary. It also lays the foundation for a continuation, as badly as I want to spend more time in this world, I would also be happy if they quit while ahead. Surely lightning can't be bottled a third time.

Not a film I anticipated with any great optimism, as Ridley Scott, the director of the first film, a masterpiece recognized only after its unspectacular theatrical performance and the oh-hum reviews, was an erratic director, to be kind. He was very capable of making movies that while boasting an attractive style, would let you down with half baked story lines and conventional Hollywood endings, whether they be     upbeat or bleak by the end of the last reel. Fortunately, smarter judgment prevailed and director Dennis Villeneuve--Sicario, Arrival, Prisoners-- was brought on bard to extend the replicant saga. Fittingly, the film is a luscious, lovingly detailed and poetically blurred vision of a polluted and decimated Los Angeles and western United States, and the enticing and confounding issues that arise from the creation of very human like androids to essentially function and exist as nothing other than a disposable slave class remain with us. The smart matter here is that the right story elements are drawn from the original film,the right characters are brought back to furnish       us with ideas as to how matters have changed over thirty years , the mysteries have deepened more so , and the mysteries remain. BR 2049 has all the issues the lured us in from the original motion picture, but it is its  own majestic,dystopian saga. It is equal parts meditation, philosophical debate, action movie, love story and, above all, a mystery, all the strands perfectly fused together seamlessly. This film is a masterpiece.

It's a crying shame this movie did so poorly and we'll likely never see another blade runner film again.

'Blade Runner 2049' is a movie that, at least for me, has been extremely anticipated for a very long time. The original 'Blade Runner' is one of my favorite sci-fi films of all-time, so when I heard that Ryan Gosling, one of my favorite actors, would be introduced into this universe, I was incredibly excited to see this. So when I finally got to see this movie, I left the theater with a new appreciation for what modern sci-fi can bring to cinema. This movie is incredible. I mean... where do I begin. The cinematography is the best I have seen in recent years, the acting from Ryan Gosling, Harrison Ford and Sylvia Hoeks is impeccable, the story itself is consistantly mind-blowing and emotionally satisfying and the ending is beyond perfect. While the pacing in this movie could be an issue for common movie-goers, I found these "slower" moments in the film to be completely made up for by the eye-pleasing cinematography executed perfectly by, the great, Roger Deakins. This return to such a beautiful, sleek yet somber world is beyond welcomed for me and many others, and the people behind the camera who worked on this movie knew exactly how to portray the futuristic version of Los Angeles.
Denis Villeneuve does amazing at directing this film. So many times we ask ourselves nowadays "Where are the new greats? Where is the next Kubrick? Where is the next Scorsese? Where is the next Tarantino? Well... I think we have found our answer. Except for Christopher Nolan, I believe Villeneuve is the next great. With films like 'Incendies', 'Enemy', 'Prisoners', 'Sicario', 'Arrival' and now 'Blade Runner 2049', this guy has yet to disappoint.
Ryan Gosling is probably my favorite actor working in Hollywood right now. He consistently chooses to be in movies that have a true meaning. With every film he is in, he is trying to have the audience walk away with something that they did not start watching the movie with. Sure, he's been in some duds, but when his acting hits, it hits hard, and he is usually my favorite part of every film he is in. His ability to disappear behind a role is unreal and truly inspiring to me.
Harrison Ford. Boy, does he bring it in this film. I was worried walking in that he would possibly sleep-walk his way through this film, but to my pleasant surprise, this is his strongest performance in the last decade. His is so good as Deckard, and he is always proving to me why he is one of my favorite actors of all-time.
Sylvia Hoeks is an actress I had no knowledge of prior to this film. When I first saw her on screen I was intrigued, but also unsettled. Her performance in this film is scary, yet mesmerizing to watch. Her character is conflicted, but knows what she has to do. Her role as the villain of this film is great. To me she is unknown, and she holds her own with great actors such as Ryan Gosling, Harrison Ford and Jared Leto.
This film has a mystery that kept me engaged for it's entire 2 hours and 45 minute run-time. I can't suggest this movie enough. If you are a 'Blade Runner' fan, you will adore this film, and even if you are a casual fan of movies in general, I am confident will have a good time watching this story unfold. 'Blade Runner 2049' was one of my favorite films of 2017.

BLADE RUNNER 2049

You know you have big shoes to fill when you have to make a sequel to every film buff's wet dream, the original sci-fi noir from Ridley Scott. This new version certainly isn't going to be as seminal or as divisive, nor will it create such a strong fanbase. However, it is to be enjoyed as what it tries to be: a well-crafted blockbuster with a unshakable ideological stand-point. Apart from plot or ideology, nonetheless, the prodigious directing of Villeneuve proves once again that he is one of the best working in the film industry today. Despite never reaching the heights of Arrival, this movie (which is not a film noir) is compelling to its core and every shot feels right at home. Contrary to many Hollywood directors, Villeneuve isn't afraid to keep some shots longer than they're expected and to compose them in an innovative way. He manages to imprint into the movie an overall sense of eeriness caused by its vastness, the off always feeling far greater than what you're watching. I would say that the only thing working against his vision is Walker's editing and some lack of character development in most of the characters. But even if it can be said that the shots are too short, the same can't be said about each scene as each one of them has room to breathe and has a narrative pay off. It's such a long movie that never gets to be cyclical or dull, as every integrant part of the movie is working together as whole to be captivating. Furthermore, the casting is fitting, especially Gosling who is balanced and grounded in that dystopian world.  However, every single element of the film is outshined by the most revolutionary and stunning cinematography of the year. You really don't expect that every single shot in a blockbuster will showcase such an amount of detail and care for visual storytelling. Even if you dislike the movie as whole, you have to appreciate the visual wonder it displays, as the color palette is crafted to a point in which it fits each scene's necessities, despite its variable content.I would say that it can be considered as one of Villeneuve's worse but it speaks volumes that it is still incredibly solid. It's a film that gets you hooked by its plot, but makes you stay for continuous technical and creative achievement. It will certainly be rewatched time and time again, and will serve as an example of a sequel done extremely right.

Blade Runner 2049 is without a doubt one of the best sequels ever created. The world of the original Blade Runner was dark, greedy and full of philosophical questions and 2049 manages to not only preserve the previous film, but expand on its predecessor. What a surprise it was to see Harrison Ford not as a cameo but a real character. Just how much of the modern films ever do that? The original film was quite slow-paced and sometimes boring to watch, but the world it showed, the questions it raised kept many fans going. And now we get this, a slightly modernized version of Ridley Scott's masterpiece. But it was modernized in a very careful way, trying to save as much of the setting as they possibly could, while improving what they couldn't. Blade Runner 2049 is still a slow film, unfolding its detective story in such a way that you can't even predict what is going to happen next. It leaves you at the edge of the seat at every plot twist you encounter. The world became even darker and harsher and the protagonist is almost always has to overcome difficulties, that he can't even grasp. All in all, Blade Runner 2049 is full of solid performance from the actors, gorgeous visuals, great camera work and atmosphere.

'BLADE RUNNER 2049' -- the far-too-long awaited sequel to a magnum opus of modern science fiction film, a film many (including myself) found to be one of the greatest films ever made, incomparable to others in its class and transcendent despite superior advancements in CGI and film technology. The original film left such a legacy because it explored Philip K. Dick's original story without sacrificing storyline or characters to popular trend mechanics. It was a simple enough tale, with few key characters and action sequences used sparingly but exceptionally. 'BLADE RUNNER 2049' not only keeps up with its predecessor, it brilliantly expands on its overall importance as a pillar of science fiction cinema. Perhaps no other actor currently in Hollywood could have fit the role of Officer K more perfectly than Ryan Gosling. His complex character rhymes with Harrison Ford's iconic Deckard to deliver pure, unmatched chemistry. Robin Wright is fantastic, Jared Leto is terrifying, and Ana de Armas delivers one of the greatest performances of the year as the film's greatest centerpiece. The cinematography, exquisitely crafted and blended by Roger Deakins, is unparalleled -- some of the most beautiful moments of filmmaking I've ever seen are proposed throughout the film's unraveling, creating a marvel of cinematic imagery that is overwhelmingly powerful. There is not much that I can come up with with regards to negative components of this film; Everything seems to work perfectly, due to Denis Villenueve's unbelievable work behind the camera and precision as an auteur director. He proves himself to be more than capable of adapting the world of Blade Runner into a sequel, something that could have gone horribly wrong in so many ways and yet surpasses all shadows of a doubt and delivers an unquestionable work of modern art. This is a glimpse into the possibilities of filmmaking that could be explored by so many talented actors, directors, writers and producers within Hollywood, but is so rarely captured as magnificently. I could not award this film anything less than a perfect score. It will remain one of my favorite films forever.

Add to that the superb directing from Villeneuve (bonus film-nerd points for K's introduction which is almost an exact, frame-by-frame replica of Scott's original idea of how to introduce Deckard) who manages to coax the absolute most out of what's available, creating an incredibly immersive atmosphere and leaving you with a subtle and affecting exploration of what it means to be human, interspersed with some heavy action sequences. It's a very different film from its predecessor (yet it still manages to feel like it's part of the same universe created by Scott all those years ago) and whether or not the slower pace, philosophical focus and contemplative tone appeals to you will be a matter of taste. I've seen this film twice now, and can assure you, that this film has blown every other 2017 movie out of the water. I loved every second of this movie, and cannot seem to find one thing critically wrong with it. Usually the more I think about a movie, or watch one that I notice things I don't like, and I've thought about Blade Runner 2049 for a solid week now. It's perfect. Director Denis Villeneuve, along with this film and his other masterpieces, has sealed himself as one of the best directors of all time, and this film is the best reason why.

The original film (a review for that will come later) is also a science fiction masterpiece, and one that people didn't think needed a sequel. It was so simplistic, yet so beautiful, and one wouldn't think that anything could be added on to it. But we got a film with the most engrossing, beautiful, and naturally evolving story lines I've ever seen. You just have to see it to believe it, and know how carefully crafted this film really is. It starts so simple but unravels itself to you so brilliantly, that it seems like everything is happening in real time. I know that's the point of a plot to unravel itself, but so many movies nowadays are so predictable, especially sequels.

The cinematography is gorgeous. Roger Deakins almost always does the cinematography for Denis Villeneuve films, and he has this subtle beauty to every single one of his shots and it makes them all so uniquely profound. Simply put, the film is shot perfectly.

The acting is great all around. Gosling fits into this world very well, and Harrison Ford reprises his role exactly how you'd imagine he would. I was hoping he wasn't just going to be old, tired Harrison Ford, but he was honestly better in this movie than he was in The Force Awakens. The girl who played "Joi" was phenomenal, and this is easily her best role.

There's not much else to say but go see this masterpiece, and watch the Final Cut of Blade Runner before you do. The themes expanded upon in this film of love and fear are so beautiful, and are done better than any other movie I've ever seen. Needless to say, it's one of the greatest movies of all time. 11 out of 10

I watched the original Blade Runner, which version I can't recall, some years ago, and I wasn't impressed all things considered. The effects were great, as was the atmosphere, cinematography and the sheer aesthetic brilliance of the dystopia being presented. When I watched Blade Runner 2049, longer than its predecessor, I found all these pros to still be intact, but what made the original such a tough sit were also true for the belated sequel. Denis Villeneuve is an excellent director who has proven himself capable of handling thinking-persons Sci-fi with Arrival. But here, in his attempts to establish a dark, brooding atmosphere, he allows shots to go on for an obscene length of time. Add to that the long pauses in conversations, the scenes of people doing nothing but staring and the interminable shots of people walking or flying ships, and you have a film which is roughly an hour longer than it needs to be. Jared Leto, a brilliant actor given prominent billing and a good chunk of the poster, is given almost nothing to do besides wander around spouting vague, Godly diatribes that contribute nothing to the story. His entire role could have been cut out and nothing would be sacrificed. Likewise, Harrison Ford is supposed to be a heavy supporting player, but gets little screen time and is rarely, if ever, the focus. I admire what the film tries to do and how it's put together, but everything takes too long to be said, if it even needs to be said at all, and scenes prattle on and on, at best without haste and at worst without purpose. Unless some heavy trimming was done, I won't be watching it again anytime soon.

Strengths: Holy crap. This movie is gorgeous. Every single frame is breathtaking. The cinematography is just splendid. With the stunning visuals out of the way, the next thing to commend is the storyline. It's compelling and gets much better as the film unravels. There are several twists and turns that really keep you on your toes. The score was magnificent, giving this film the trio of great direction, score, and writing. Then, there's the acting. Ryan Gosling (K) was a great choice to take over as the lead. He consistently shows his range, giving a great performance once again. His scenes with Harrison Ford (Rick Deckard) weren't plentiful, but they were highlights. The stuff where Rick chases K through his Las Vegas home is some of my favorite stuff all year long, and 2017 was a great year for movies. Ana de Armas (Joi) was quietly the show stealer. Though she's an AI, there's a humanness to her character and you really feel for her. At first, I thought the sex scene was possibly a waste of time, but it added to her relationship with K and made what happens to her mean even more. The other small roles are all well-acted, from Robin Wright (Lt. Joshi) to Dave Bautista (Sapper Morton) to Jared Leto (Niander Wallace) and everyone in between, there are no bad performances.

Weaknesses: At 163 minutes, this is one long film. It feels a bit longer because there isn't a lot of action, especially in the first half. It can be tough to maintain focus while some of the story unravels. Though I though Leto was fine in the role, I wasn't a big fan of the Wallace character. He didn't fit the antagonist role the way I hoped he would

Overall: Once again, Denis Villeneuve delivers. This film took a slew of talented people (Gosling, Villeneuve, Ford, cinematographer Rodger Deakins, etc.) and gave them the platform to deliver a memorable show. It's exactly what I want from a sci-fi film. A great story, masterful visuals, and a fantastical world. One of the best films of a crowded 2017.
