It's been years since I've experienced a movie in theatres where almost every image left me in awe. Not impressed, not merely captivated, but in awe. In most "good looking" films, it's easy to find several scenes in images where your eyes feel like shrugging compared to the rest of the film's imagery. It was difficult to find very many scenes like that in Blade Runner 2049. Even when there's next to no visual action going on in the frame, these images still find a way to impress. But thankfully, there's more to Blade Runner 2049 than just pretty pictures. Director Denis Villeneuve never forgets that this is a Blade Runner movie, a dark mystery about what it really means to be human in a world filled to the brim with advanced technology. The lovely visuals aid the story, instead of trying to bury it.

If you're looking for a critic to explain the plot of Blade Runner 2049 to you, I'm afraid you're in the wrong place. Not just because of the director's wishes against spoilers, but also because experiencing a story taking place is much better than having it summed up in a few paragraphs. But for those seeking the basics of the plot, here they are: it takes place in the future, it involves a cop, and he's investigating something.

If I still have your attention, then let's carry on with the review. Like the first movie, Blade Runner 2049 is also a movie that needs to be experienced. The darker and harsher world of this film can't be effectively conveyed without the movie's performances, sound design, and visual effects. For starters, going back on our earlier point, the movie is a special visual experience. So much so that thanking one crew member for the look of the film would be extremely unfair. So equal praise should go to everybody involved with the technical side of this project, not just to a clever director and cinematographer.

The dingy streets and neon lights effectively convey a similar atmosphere that was established in the first film. But the common holograms, unusual architecture, and vast landscapes show that this is a world that has evolved and changed since 2019, and not necessarily for the better. Holograms are either used as in-your-face advertising (sometimes literally) or simple tools designed to tell you what you want to hear and fulfill your unfulfilled desires. Vast landscapes throughout the film are often too vast and too empty, often dwarfing the main character in their sheer size and emptiness. And the unusual architecture, even when it seems to be made out of wood, feels designed rather than constructed. In fact, very few things in this world seem real, even an attempt at dinner from Detective K (Ryan Gosling) looks like it was made from plastic. And the only real constructions left in this world are either abandoned or salvaged. This is a world that is equal measures fascinating and horrifying, like gazing into a potential future for mankind.

The sound design also really helps in bringing this troubled world to life. The musical score, while lacking the magic of Vangelis's score for the original film, still works in harmony with the moods and emotions for each scene. From throat-singing in Wallace's (Jared Leto) chamber, to the menacing drums used for a futuristic L.A.P.D. tower, to the playful chimes used in Detective K's romantic encounters with the optimistic Joi (Ana De Armas); these little touches in the soundtrack truly emphasize the emotion of each scene. Again, supporting the film, not trying to make up for it. It's a miracle that this soundtrack turned out as good as it did, considering the last minute change of composers and the fact that the soundtrack is almost entirely original. And of course, a dystopia could never come to life without convincing sound effects, and Blade Runner 2049 is no exception. This is an overused statement, but every sound used outside of the soundtrack truly feels real. No blaster sounds, no explosions that sound way quieter than they should, and no other silly overused sci-fi sound effects. Every bang, crash, jump, shot, step, and yell sounds exactly like it should. For example, in Dave Bautista's scene, we originally find him farming in a heavy radioactive suit. And with that moment, we can hear the heavy steps, echoes, and breathing that would go on in such a suit. The audience is there in his suit, and we didn't need any cheap POV or overlong establishing shots to get that level of immersion. It's such a short, inconsequential scene, but it's impressive that even the smallest scenes in Blade Runner 2049 are trying to pull you into its world instead of pushing you away.

And then, we arrive at the final stage of crafting a fictional world: the characters. Admittedly, there are few characters that feel like they never get any time to properly develop. Although, looking back at the film, maybe that's because I enjoyed their company so much. Ryan Gosling, an actor who should win the most improved actor award at this point, is perfect as a morally conflicted detective. I truly believed every step of his struggle, every emotion he conveyed, and every blow to his face. And this is all done without a shred of overacting or "phoning it in", so to speak. Harrison Ford, reprising his role as Deckard, feels like he's actually acting this time. I was afraid that he was gonna "Bruce Willis" this important role, but he actually delivered. Is it because Harrison actually cares about this character? Or because the director cared enough to get him to actually act? Who knows? What matters is that he conveys a character that is both emotionally devastated and slightly desensitized to his previous events. All of the actors also suit their characters quite well, especially Jared Leto as Wallace and Ana De Armas as Joi. The actors certainly make the film's world all the more interesting and emotional, even when the story and writing fail to do so.

Sadly, the actual story behind Blade Runner 2049 can be pretty flawed at times. There are certain aggravating moments in the movie that call back to previous dialogue (even dialogue that literally just occurred) designed as "A-Ha!" moments for the audience. While this was an issue with the original Blade Runner, this is an issue that really should have remained buried in the past. It feels like pandering to the audience, and that the film doesn't respect the audience's intelligence as much as it should. This also carries on into the dialogue. Sometimes, the dialogue can rely a bit too much on clunky exposition, sometimes spelling out whole backstories to the audience like living audio logs. I get that the writers wanted to expand the world of Blade Runner more in this sequel, but it's a shame that they couldn't find more clever ways to do so in these moments. On even fewer occasions, the dialogue can sound outright unnatural, even if it's coming out of the mouth of an android.

It truly shows how special this film is, however, that these seemingly big flaws are somehow inconsequential and end up feeling like minor annoyances more than anything. This is still an intriguing mystery story with a lot of tricks up it's sleeve, even for longtime fans of Blade Runner and dystopian Science Fiction. It's also impressive that the film never loses touch of it's themes, like the first film this is still a story about how life and reality can even be considered special in a society filled with technology and prejudice. And it's a breath of fresh air that every aspect of the film effectively conveys that message, instead of just a clever script and a few great performances. Yes, the film isn't quite as smart or clever as it's predecessor, but any movie that gets even close to reaching the magic of Blade Runner is well worth your time. The visual experience alone is worth the price of admission, but thankfully there's so much more lurking beneath the smooth surface.

See it in IMAX if you can.

There are great films, then there are films that can change your life.

I've seen 3 films that left a mark and changed the way I feel and think. These films also changed my perception on movies in general and they are very much reflected on my works.

Fight Club

Memento

(500) Days of Summer

I never saw any of these films in the theater. I was too young when Fight Club and Memento were released while I didn't even remember (500) Days of Summer being released. So in a way I never truly had a complete experience with those films. Films are and will always be meant to be seen in the big screen (sorry, streaming). I always wanted to watch a movie that I will love in the cinema.

And that's what exactly happened last Sunday when I watched Blade Runner 2049.

I am in no way a critic. I am just a fan and a lover of films. So allow me to indulge myself by writing why Blade Runner 2049 became one of my favorite films of all time.

Let me start by saying that I didn't like the original Blade Runner. I know it sounds blasphemous considering it's a cult classic and is highly regarded as one of the most influential sci-fi films of all time. But for me, it felt too dragging and predictable at times. So I went to see 2049 with tempered expectations. I mean, I could've just skipped it and waited for it on HBO but seeing director Denis Villeneuve's previous works (Prisoners, Enemy, Sicario, Arrival) I had this gut feel that he would do something special. I'm glad I didn't skip because my gut feel was damn right.

Rarely do you see a blockbuster filled with depth and so many layers. After the credits rolled all I could say was "What?" because it's tough to digest everything at first. But after thinking about it, together with reading articles and watching videos about it, I started to understand the movie which eventually led to me loving it. I read comments about it saying that the film tried to say a lot of things which eventually resulted in it being messy. While I agree that the film tries to say a lot, I don't think that it's messy. For me, it actually depicted the mind of someone who's asking what it means to be human. Asking that question will lead to more questions than answers. That is what happens to Ryan Gosling's Officer K.

Officer K is somehow trying to find his place in the world. This resonates with me a lot because I'm at the point in my life where I feel lost and I can't seem to figure out where I should be. The film also asks what it means to be alive and what it is that makes us special. K lived his entire life knowing that he's just a replicant hunting other replicants. Nothing more, nothing less. So when he discovered something that showed him he might be more than just a Blade Runner, he believed it. He believed that he is special, that there is more to his life than just the routine. He believed that there is more to him that what people say. That was the first time he felt truly special. But it turns out (spoiler alert!) that he's just a decoy. He wasn't so special after all. In a way, I can connect with that as well. Sometimes I ask myself if there's more to life than the routine and the norm. Like K, I want to be special. I want to feel like I'm important and I mean something. I grew up in an environment where people downplay this longing and tell me I shouldn't go after what I want. It makes me think that I'm just a peg in a board game and someone else is playing it. I feel like a small piece in a grand scheme just like how the replicants are. It makes me feel irrelevant. Eventually, K accepted the fact that he's just a piece and played his part knowing that there's a bigger picture. I think he felt like that was his true purpose, being one of the catalysts of change. Unlike K though, I've yet to accept that I'm just a peg and I still haven't discovered my true individual purpose.

Blade Runner 2049 is a hot mess. I've seen it twice now and have tried to gather a concise view on the film that everyone hails to be a masterpiece and a future classic. In that respect, nah, it's not a future classic but if you were ever going to make a sequel to Blade Runner - Denis Villeneuve has done the best he could do. But what does that say about the film? First off, Blade Runner 2049 is simply gorgeous and has been crafted with such care and respect to the original film and its world building that it's astounding how one could actually pull it off. Roger Deakins' cinematography elevates the immaculate production design to a whole other level showcasing a grotty dystopian future that still retains Deakins' sterile style yet still looking lived in and palpable. The late added score by Hans Zimmer feels interpolated with notes and tones from the illustrious Vangelis score from the original while at the same time pushing the envelope and even drawing from other sci-fi influences like the use of choral voices like Ligeti in 2001: A Space Odyssey. I as well happen to really like the slow pacing of the film which gives the subject matter time to breathe and allows its cast to really flesh out their performances. Dave Bautista, Ana de Armas and Sylvia Hoeks are fantastic in their supporting roles while Harrison Ford himself returns and is at the top of his game. At first I felt he was a little out of character from how I always remembered Deckard, but later when Ford gives a raw and moving performance while being confronting and questioned about his past truly showcased a range that I thought Ford had lost decades ago. However, the best thing about the film for me is the character of "K" and the awards worthy performance by Ryan Gosling. Ryan Gosling's character arc is beautiful, heartbreaking and visceral. The Kafka-esque nature of his character and the trials (get it?) and tribulations his character goes through gives the film true heart - something that the original Blade Runner actually failed to really provide. 
But now we get onto the messy negatives. Right off the bat, just because the script was around in the 80's and that this story was always intended to be the sequel does not add quality to the story. Which is my all round problem with the film - the plot. If someone told you before the film began what the plot of the film was you would laugh. Upon seeing it a second time the on-paper plot did not bother me as much because I was more compelled by Gosling's character K more than anything else. To me, Blade Runner 2049 also rides the line shakily between Sony blockbuster and Art House project. It's not quite one and it's not quite the other. If there was more focus and an edit to remove (in my opinion) a little fluff here and there, then conceptually and narratively the film would be more concise and less muddled. Especially in regards as to why the antagonists and protagonists are in conflict. Blade Runner 2049 indeed dances with the idea of the philosophical nature of its predecessor but does it by saying the themes rather than displaying them however the ending of the film is rather sweet and has a very understated parallel with the original film. All hyperbole aside though, I feel this sequel has somewhat tainted some parts of my viewing/reading of the original film. Don't get me wrong; I did not want a re-hash of the original movie nor did I want a carbon copy. What I had hoped for was a film that bares the same tone and themes that understands that Blade Runner was a detective Noir picture that in the background was Science Fiction film rather than the other way around. And I guess I kinda got that, with a few flaws. On my first viewing around the half way mark I clicked that this is a great big expensive fan film. However - giving it time and a second viewing, I am less harsh and I stand by my opening statement that if they were ever going to make a sequel i'm glad it was done by someone who really cares about the universe and that Denis has done the best he could. Just please for the love of christ don't make another. I couldn't bare the thought of a Blade Runner cinematic universe. Please. PLEASE!

Fan Fiction! Blade Runner 2049 is a very sophisticated piece of fan fiction. It seems that all these later day sequels and prequels (such as Alien Covenant, Prometheus and Star Wars) have one thing in common; they over-explain the original source material to the point of being revisionist and thus destroy the mysteries that were the essence of the original's lasting appeal. Blade Runner 2049 fits the same pattern.  Visually sublime, it definitely is, to the point of near perfection. But then again, the director Denis Villeneuve had the best source material to get inspiration from (i.e. the original 1982 Blade Runner film). The cinematography by Roger Deakins is a serious study in how to stretch the limits of German expressionism, with its canted angles and chiaroscuro reflections of water; it would be just if the Oscar goes in his direction. But what makes the heart slide when watching Blade Runner 2049 is that, beneath the beautiful visage, it has no heart. It substitutes the original's quest to classify the soul with a preoccupation with how to classify a species (the newly emergent self-reproducing Replicants). The narrative is a Lego-clump of various sci-fi themes, from the underground army awaiting their messiah, with their prophetic female leader (like the Fremen from David Lynch's 'Dune') to having a precious female of the new species that needs to be protected (i.e. Alfonso Cuaron's 'Children of Men') to the outright theft of the A.I./ human-avatar love making scene taken complete from Spike Jonze's 'Her'. The film has set the bar high for what can be imagined for a future dystopian world. But, it's the aspirations of the story that let the film down. It attempts to ask the big questions, but these seem hastily tagged on to an uninspiring story on species classification that is chewed upon for a prolonged 164 mins. The film is obsessed with visual perfection to the point of cold savagery. This perfection hides a cold heart and is summed up by the disguising of actress Sean Young's real face with a lagging 'more perfect' CGI version. Ironically Sean Young is given a cameo credit for this 'appearance'.

I had doubts about whether the sequel would be able to faithfully follow the original's stunning soundscape and entrancing visuals, but it stayed faithfully close to both, almost to a fault. While the world expanded into territories unseen in the first Blade Runner, it felt consistent and continuous and not like a departure, but the city realm remained nearly identical to its past incarnation, bringing up questions about how this civilization seemed unchanged after thirty years. In the end, I would prefer its direct reduplication of the earlier sets over a less satisfying new interpretation. 
The soundtrack borrows heavily from the original Vangelis score, but boosts its power in a way more congruent with composer Hans Zimmer's more canon, and maybe tired, booming compositions. The score pushes the mood of the film persistently into a deeper and darker place, and left me emotionally fatigued. The single standout weakness of the film was the lack of compelling antagonists. Blade Runner 2049's are far from the compelling portrayals of Roy and Pris who round out the counterpoints to the philosophical questions posed in the original. Instead, we get Jared Leto outfitted with white contacts and a bionic ear implant, I suppose to not so subtly emphasize that he is a strange and evil outsider, with attempts at poetic philosophical musings that come off more like entries from the diary of a moody teenager who has just read his first Camus novel. Leto's android assistant never quite comes together as a coherent character, and seems to waver inexplicably between cold immorality and bursts of empathy.
The most absorbing moments are spent with K, played by Ryan Gosling with a reticence we have come to expect from him. His silent, meaningful stares provide breathing space in a film that could be overwhelming with its expansive sound and images. 
Blade Runner 2049 may not take many risks, but provides a stunning homage to the original and will leave you quiet and reflective in its immersive exploration of what it means to be real.

BORED TO (GORGEOUS) TEARS IN RAIN - My Review of BLADE RUNNER 2049 (3 Stars? 4 Stars? 5 Stars? I'm soooo torn!)

Let's get this out of the way.  I've never been a huge BLADE RUNNER fan.  I've seen every released cut of Ridley Scott's film, and with narration, without narration, with outtakes from THE SHINING as Harrison Ford and Sean Young fly to a more promising future, or a more convincing ending argument that Deckard is a replicant, I always found it to be a visually astounding bore.  It's a slow moving, some would say ponderous, film noir tricked up with game-changing special effects...yet I've always been drawn to it.  I love dystopian tales, and this one, about a detective hunting down rogue replicants who escaped slavery and came to an acid rain-soaked Los Angeles to live more freely, is as bleak as they come.  Rutger Hauer brought so much life to his performance that everyone else's felt so self-serious.  Sure, living in this world would not have felt like a day at Disneyland, but man what a scowl-a-thon!

Set 30 years after the events of the first film, Denis Villeneuve (ARRIVAL, PRISONERS) and writers Hampton Fancher (who wrote the original) and Michael Green (LOGAN, AMERICAN GODS), we meet K, a new-world replicant LAPD detective who discovers something suspicious on one of his routine rounds to dispose of an older model.  There's an interesting dynamic that Gosling gets to play, and play well, as his character struggles to kill his own kind.  He spends a LOT of time staring at things, but his intensely coiled emotions get their release in a scene both staggering and surprising.  

I won't spoil the story, but it introduces a slew of memorable characters.  Robin Wright plays the LAPD Chief of Police further cementing her career phase as the go-to-gal for icy, intense leaders.  Ana De Armas as Joi, K's girlfriend of sorts, brings a Gal Gadot style of performance and is a part of some of the film's most arresting visual tricks.  Mackenzie Davis seems to be an alternate universe version of Darryl Hannah's Pris from the original, but with a completely different agenda. Carla Juri plays a doctor whose role will remain a mystery in this review, but I want to note that she's heartbreaking.  Jared Leto as Wallace, the blind CEO of a corporation that has taken over for the original's evil Tyrell, delivers a quiet, subtle turn, which just might be the biggest surprise of all!  His partner-in-crime, Luv (Sylvia Hoeks), just about walks away with the film as one of the most intensely aggressive foes since the T-2000. Since he's on the poster, it shouldn't be a surprise that Ford makes an appearance.  With a brief amount of screen time, his story is integral to the goings-on and contains the biggest twist.  

So why am I not passionate about this film?  I don't know.  Maybe I am.  I mean, the cinematography by Roger Deakins is awe-inspiring.  Every single shot of this movie made me gasp.  EVERY SINGLE SHOT.  It's hard to believe Deakins has never won an Oscar despite 13 nominations, so can we please correct this horrible oversight next year?  So much stays true to the original aesthetic in the city scenes, but where Deakins triumphs is in the new world building with such disparate landscapes as a hazy farm, a sunburned Las Vegas, or inside the LAPD where K occasionally goes to recalibrate.  Those scenes in particular will stay with me; the repetitious questions and answers and the urgency of the sound design.  

The score by Hans Zimmer and Benjamin Wallfisch combined with the incredible sound editing  feels like a relentless wall of sound.  Its sustained intensity and disorienting qualities are the one factor that made me think Villeneuve is making his version of a Christopher Nolan movie.  At nearly three hours, the sound creates the feeling that the film is just one long sustained scene.  After a while, however, it made me a little restless and bored.  I wanted some levity, some oasis of silence instead of the constant pummeling.  Yes, there's originality in all of the creepy sounds, but despite the endless pauses and staring, the movie needed to both be shortened and be allowed to breathe.  It's a Catch 22 I cannot wrap my head around.  It's an almost perfect film that's also perfectly punishing.   At times, I just wanted out.  It's how I felt when I would watch MR ROBOT, which I gave up on in Season 2.  It's bold and visionary and yet, such a chore, such a slog, and an experience that made me want to sign up for a Silkwood shower stat.  

BLADE RUNNER 2049 isn't quite as vile, because of those visuals, and also because its story has a beating heart.  But it does go on and on.  In fact, tonally it feels a lot like the original.  There's a quiet, meditative film about what it's like to be human, buried under an aural cacophony.  Like all good science fiction, it challenges you to ponder who deserves this planet, mankind or machines?  Despite some exciting set pieces, it seems more fitting to call these movies BLADE CRAWLER.  All of this is to say, I loved it, I hated it, my world has been rocked and put to sleep by it.  It's either a masterpiece or a mess-terpiece, which, considering the dystopian present we're in, makes it one of THE movies of the year somehow!

Blade Runner 2049 comes 35 years after Ridley Scott's 1982 film, amid a gale of trepidation and uncertainty about whether it will improve, or even stand up to the original film, now widely recognised as an influential cult classic. Every sequel is required to prove itself worthy of its predecessor, and there is always a massive weight on the film makers' shoulders to create something which can expand the ideas, story and characters set up in the first. With Blade Runner, this was a monumental task, undertaken with little apprehension and a great deal of skill by director Denis Villeneuve. The result is, in the words of Kingsman's Taron Egerton: "F**king spectacular"!

Denis Villeneuve (with Ridley Scott on production duties) has managed to craft a breathtaking piece of landmark cinema which lives up to the adoration fans have for the original Blade Runner (myself included), while also introducing the world to a new generation. The word "world" there, seems a bit out-of-place however. While Ridley Scott showed himself to be a master world-builder in 1982, Denis Villeneuve has taken Scott's world and expanded it into a fully fleshed out, living, breathing universe. This is partly down to the script and story, but can be mostly attributed to director of photography, Roger Deakins. The cinematography of 2049 bleeds with meaning and seeps beauty, and every frame is transportative and almost interactive - I am not ashamed to admit to several gasps and a stray tear here and there, due to the sheer beauty of this film, something which Villeneuve managed to pull off last year with Arrival, and which Deakins has achieved time and time again throughout his career (especially in his collaborations with Villeneuve on Sicario and Prisoners). This NEEDS to be seen on a massive screen - IMAX if you can, but just make sure it's big! Since 2049's release, many critics have said that it would be criminal for Deakins to miss out on another Oscar win. I hate to jump on the band wagon, but I may just have to on this one. Give him that bloody golden statue already!

The editing also has to be given a great deal of credit here too. 2049 has a deeper, more complex story than the original, which can twist and turn in ways which may seem slightly conventional at first, but turn out incredibly well. However, despite the rich story, 2049 does not suffer from a dearth of quiet moments. In fact, it is is edited with an almost languorous care which provides countless moments in which we can marvel at the scenery, study the characters' multifaceted expressions or simply bask in the other-worldly, reverberating score. And that score... oh boy! If you see this in IMAX, or any cinema with a fantastic sound system (which I highly recommend), be warned: your organs will be shaken, your bones will tremble, your mind WILL be blown!

While the audience already had stakes in this movie in the shape of Harrison Ford's Deckard, we are introduced to new, deeply rich characters which capture our attention, curiosity and even our love. Gosling's "K", and his intriguing relationship with Ana de Armas's "Joi", are set against the dark and dreary backdrop of dystopian LA, and we get to explore the hellish cityscape (which, like the original, is punctuated with abrasive neon lights and drenched in acid rain) through their ever-expressive eyes. And it's the eyes which say the most in 2049, a movie which manages to say just as much with the macro (massive wide-shots taking in the scenery) as it does with the micro (intense close-ups of Gos, letting us see every single pore and pimple). Whether we're being shown eyes gouged out, or exploring the complexities of emotion through Harrison Ford's coming-to-terms with his past, the characters' eyes are truly the window into 2049's soul. 

However, while 2049 does explore very much the same themes as the original, this does not mean that we have heard all this before and there's no more to say. It's quite the opposite in fact, as 2049 expands on the questions of the first, and continues to ask what it means to be human, what we should aspire to be... and whether it really matters at all. All this is managed without the self parody or meta-awareness which was present in JJ Abrams' reboots of Star Trek and Star Wars. Nobody references the "tears of rain" speech and there is no mention of paper unicorns. The only moment which almost verges on fan service is a surprise cameo, which ends up being such an interesting interaction which actually serves the story, that it can't be faulted.

There is an almost nihilistic edge to the film, that the original also bore, which may be a reason for it currently not doing as well as expected at the Box Office. Perhaps, just as in 1982, the dark, introspective themes explored in Blade Runner are just not as palatable for mainstream audiences as studios would like. Perhaps, just as with the first, 2049 will become a cult classic, influencing the film makers of tomorrow, while garnering a loyal, protective fan base in the process.

After we have said all this, about Blade Runner 2049 being an undeniable masterpiece, the big question is: is it better than the first? The knee-jerk reaction for me would be to say yes. 2049 is more swooping in scope, more intricate in detail and boasts, arguably, more emotive performances. However, we may have to wait some time to see the effect 2049 has on audiences in the years to come. Will it influence film the way Ridley Scott did in 1982, or will it simply be assigned the role of "surprisingly good sequel"? One thing is certain at this point: Denis Villeneuve is going on to be a fantastic, ground-breaking film maker. You sometimes hear that there aren't currently any great directors, who could have the cultural impact of such legends as Hitchcock or Kubrick. However, when we look at the work of Villeneuve with Prisoners, Sicario, Arrival and now Blade Runner, we can be sure that we are witnessing the rise of a fine film maker, who will no doubt one day be seen as one of the greats.
-S
Verdict: Blade Runner 2049 is a masterpiece of world-building, storytelling, editing, cinematography and acting. It's satisfying enough to watch any sequel which lives up to the original, but with something as iconic and influential as Blade Runner being given such nurtured adoration, we can't help but think we're witnessing a landmark moment in cinema. So good that even Roy Batty wouldn't believe his eyes.

Well, it sure is a Denis Villeneuve film. I've read comparisons between him and Spielberg, but this couldn't be further from the truth - Villeneuve seems to be focused on the 'art' of movies; all his films look spectacular, sound stunning, and are shot to perfection, but everything else seems to fall into a distant second place. BR2049 takes this to another level, because it looks *so* good, and the Hans Zimmer soundtrack is *so* amazing,  while the film is chock full of good ideas (some that work, some that don't) and the performances are decent enough (though Leto walks a fine line at times) that disparity becomes ever increasing and detracts from the movie. It's like trying to explore an art gallery while simultaneously reading a good book - it doesn't work.

As for the run-time; I didn't mind it, but it is unquestionably glacially paced. Certain scenes did feel unnecessarily overlong for the sake of it, but I will take that, as it was a refreshing change from the over-edited cutting of most modern flicks. The few action scenes do benefit from this, in that you can actually tell what is happening on-screen, which surprisingly is not always the case with modern cinema (Michael Bay) but the run-time could have been significantly reduced (The original hovered around the two hour mark).

Speaking of the original - the best thing I can say about this sequel, is, although it is distinctly a Denis Villeneuve film (whether that is a good or bad thing is down to personal taste) it does feel part of the Blade Runner universe, and a biotic continuation of the first film. Villeneuve seems to understand what made the first film great, and while adding his own touches to proceedings, he does rely on the guts of that film for the core here - an example being the soundtrack - it has those rumbles he is renowned for, but there is some Vangelis-esque tones in there. It builds life from the DNA of it's predecessor, rather than replicating it (no pun intended) but tells it's own story.

1 of the most rewarding, intelligent and moving movies I have ever seen in my life. After last night's view I am still in shock and astounded by the masterpiece I had the privilege to witness. I am absolutely delighted how Hollywood allowed Deni Villeneuve to direct his work without inserting formulaic shallow mindless action clips to satisfy the new ADD generation. Firstly the cinematography alone is worth more than the admission price, if Deacons does not win an Oscar for this then he never will. The casting and performances are superb beyond words, K's brief moments of emotion explosive in intensity. This is an incredibly sad story with strong messages about racism, humanity and the pointless cycle of violence. As violent as 2049 is it is visually quite mild compared to Scott's BR, revealing Villeneuve's disdain for gratuitous such. Non the less it does not make the scenes of violence any less intense as he is a master at conveying atmospheres of terror without patently showing it. I don't even know were to begin at just how multi layered and complex the story is, even at the generously slow pacing I at many times struggled to keep up and process all the information. The scenes of death and conflict explode with such intensity it's heartbreakingly visceral. In many ways I can see in this work what Ridley Scott so wanted to film but was restricted due to technical and budgetary constraints, noticeably K's retirement of Sapper at the protein farm. No dialogue wasted in this script and each fragment of info revealed vital to understanding the story. This will be a frustrating movie for any casual viewer hoping for some spoon fed escapism, action and wit. Box office sales ratings mean nothing here, see Emoji movie, enough said. It's glad that there are studios out there willing to throw huge budget to produce a risky neo-noir science fiction follow up to a 1982's film not well known by audiences at this era, knowing the fact that the box office run would possibly be catastrophic. From the director of Arrival and Sicario, this sequel set up 30 years after the original film is a rare continuation that sticks well to its thematic elements, with Villeneuve's direction of unnerving calm throughout the film that slowly expanding the universe, exploring and further synthesising the sensibility between human and mechanics. There are flaws, perhaps the two main complaints would be its unexpectedly loose ending and a running time of 163 minutes that certainly challenges the patience of audiences. Not to expect action packed or fantasy, it is a total pure, detailed and quiet science fiction carrying the significance moral dilemma of cyber punk future in a haunting, beautifully engineered and aurally spectacular visual effects as well as serene yet compelling scores from Hans Zimmer and Benjamin Wallfisch which fit the atmosphere perfectly. Great chemistry between Ryan Gosling and Harrison Ford further enhances the viewing experience, though the entire film actually acts as a divisive art crafted for a niche of serious moviegoers who would truly enjoy its deeply resonant philosophy.

'Blade Runner 2049' somehow manages to perfectly defy any expectations we might about a modern Hollywood sequel to a classic genre film. 
This isn't just slapping a marketable name onto yet another rapidly cut, CGI action fest. This isn't chock full of nudges and winks at the original for the sake of being cute. And this definitely isn't just a remake masquerading as a sequel. 
Instead, the remarkably talented Denis Villeneuve has presented us with something wholly originally. It exists in the dazzling world that Ridley Scott created for us and reintroduces us to characters we know, but it also gives us new things to think about, new mysteries to solve, and absolutely stunning imagery to get lost in. 
This is a rich and captivating piece of sci-fi cinema led by a tremendous performance by Ryan Gosling and I can't wait to see it again to further explore its treasures.

"Blade Runner 2049" is drop dead gorgeous. I cannot count how many times I looked at the film in awe of what was on screen. Each of these shots, backed up by a loud, fantastic sci-fi score, is destined to amaze each viewer. It is no doubt that the film is directed perfectly. However, the direction is clouded by a simple plot and an very long run time. While "Blade Runner 2049" tries to expand on the 1982 classic, it falls due to a near 3 hours run time and a lackluster story.

The film begins with Officer K (Ryan Gosling) flying over to a farm owned by a Nexus 6 replicant. Officer K, a replicant Blade Runner of the LAPD, is sent over to "retire" the owner, which leads to a brutal battle between the two of them. In the aftermath, Officer K scans the rest of the area to find a box buried deep below a tree. This would lead to a box of bones, leading Officer K to question who he really is and what his purpose is. Without going into too much detail (aka minor spoiler), the initial investigation in the box of bones hints that replicants may be able to reproduce. This leads to a collision course between Niander Wallace (Jared Leto), a replicant manufacturer who has built them to obey commands, and Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford), a former LAPD Blade Runner who has been missing for 30 years.

If you are confused by that last paragraph, I will assume that you have never watched the 1982 "Blade Runner." It is imperative that you watch the first film before seeing "Blade Runner 2049." While the film does give some background, it acts as more of a refresher for viewers who have already seen the first film. There are flashbacks to the original film but only viewers who have seen the film will truly understand their significance.

While there are some high points in the film (direction, score, acting), they are clouded by an overstretched plot. The plot itself is interesting. The major aspect that damages the story is the run time. In shot, this is a two hour plot that takes nearly 3 hours to finish. At least one-third of the film is padded with fluff that should have been cut out of the final version of the film. One example is the weird sex scene between Officer K, his holographic wife, and a prostitute. While I understand Director Denis Villeneuve was trying to create a visual spectacle - as well as develop Officer K's character - but the scene lasted five minutes longer than what it needed to be. There are a few more instances like this that do not affect the storyline that could have been cut.

Another mixed reaction is the use of Harrison Ford in the film. It is understandable that Ford's presence in the film helps advertise the film to new audiences, his character was not needed. The plot did not need his character in the film. While it was great to see Deckard return for the second film, his appearance is limited. With the character physically in the film for only 45 of the film makes me question if the addition of Deckard was more for promoting the film than a necessity for the story. It would have been easier if the film stuck to flashbacks rather than a full appearance from Deckard.

"Bade Runner 2049" was a disappointment. Clocking in at 164 minutes, the film is too long for a plot that only needed two-thirds of that run time to complete. The film is directed beautifully. However, a beautiful film cannot hide a long run time and a less-than complicated plot.

Grade: D+

Reviewed 10.8.17.  They did it. They managed to not screw up the sequel. Phew. With mood and aesthetic sitting front and center in the original, the creative challenge for 2049 must have been daunting. To the rescue comes a strong script, that manages to increase the emotional heft of the plot, without dropping the stark bleak nature of it all. Quite a feat. Entering the film's final act, thoughts of 'instant classic' began to run through my brain. But when it came time to tie the bow, it just wasn't tight enough. Perhaps one subplot too many.  Or for some, too open-ended of a finish (but if you've seen the original, you shouldn't have expected anything else).  What makes the best parts of these movies great is the sense of openness spewed out across a desolate canvas. Simple, but deep. Intense, but meditative. Cold, but emotional. Hence, it does not wear additional clutter well. Thankfully, it doesn't stray too far. It's a big budget movie that has retained its art house panache. And a sequel that doesn't sell out to new generation expectations. Which is why like the original, its pinnacle success is likely cult status, yet again. It's an artistic badge of honor. Bravo.

Having not been a fan of the original, I went into 2049 with an open mind.  I was hoping to have a truly epic sci-fi experience that honors the original but also stands on its own.  While 2049 does that, it still isn't resonating with me the way I think it does with most people.

I honestly can't pinpoint the reason why I'm not connecting to these films.  Great performances, beautiful cinematography, visceral action (in the limited action sequences), and a director at the top of his game, and I'm still not connecting the dots as to why these movies are viewed with such high regard.  Granted, Roger Deakins' cinematography is some of the best I have ever seen.  Gosling, Ford, and the rest of the ensemble all fit perfectly with their characters (see - Jared Leto for example).  Villeneuve proposes some fantastic story beats that definitely separate this film thematically from the original (which was a worry I had), and yet I'm still not all the way there.

I think the thing that kills me with both films is the pacing.  It's not like I haven't seen science fiction films with slow pacing that I liked. Heck, Villeneuve made a great one just last year with Arrival.  But there's something about how slow these films play and the material that drives them just doesn't resonate with me.  Whether it's the overabundance of A.I driven sci-fi features that I've seen before these movies, the bleak tone, or the fact that I just don't really care whether or not Rick Deckard is a replicant or not, Blade Runner just isn't for me.

With that said, I can always appreciate when a film is sharply put together.  Just because I'm not a fan of the material, doesn't mean I can't see when a film is something special in the technical way.  If there was ever a guy who should win the Oscar for cinematography, it's Roger Deakins.  The man has gone on long enough without a statue.  And there's nothing I can knock too much about Villeneuve's directing, even with an incredibly slow burn way of telling a story.  I thought Gosling and Ford played well off each other, and gave some of the more emotional turns I've seen from either of them in quite some time.  And the eerie but lively score from Ben Wallfisch and Hans Zimmer are among this year's best.

However overall, I can't see myself sitting down for a second viewing.  I'm perfectly content with letting other people enjoy this series.  I won't blame anyone for calling this or the original a classic.  But I'll pass.

For a modern big budget film, this one was OK. However, it failed to evoke any feelings whatsoever. A dissection below.

Good things first. The movie is visually brilliant. It is believably rough and dirty where it needs to be, and stunningly beautiful when the story allows more artful scenes. There are some good acting performances (Harrison Ford, Dave Bautista (!), Barkhad Abdi). The basic plot is OK, one could build a very good movie around it. I very much liked how the movie handled the theme of relationships and contemplated to what extent AI could replace a physical partner. And the direct references and links to the original Blade Runner movie were very clever and graceful, they did not feel like fan service at all but natural and integral parts of this movie.

Why did it fail to evoke any emotions, then? (Disclaimer: most of the reasons are probably due to personal preferences, very subjective. Your experience may be completely different.)

One issue was the editing and pacing of the film. Pacing worked very well in the beginning, but the flow was lost somewhere in the middle, and the latter half of the movie was stagnant on several occasions, losing its grip of the viewer as a result. There were also a couple of occasions where despite the tranquil pace the movie failed to present key plot developments in a clear manner -- what exactly happened, why something was done, or how did we end up in this situation from the end of the last related scene.

Second issue was a combination of casting and screen writing. Ryan Gosling is a solid actor, but perhaps best suited to sympathetic heartthrob roles; in my opinion he lacks the kind of rugged charisma and screen presence that would be needed for playing this kind of role with such vast screen time. However, the role is extremely challenging -- to function as a focal point of the whole movie he should be identifiable, charismatic, memorable; on the other hand he should convincingly portray a machine without a free will whose job is to kill his own kind. Gosling makes a brave effort, but the end result is bland. The antagonists are simply trite. Jared Leto is miscast, stale at best and atrocious at worst; instead of a menacing, wildly ambitious genius he comes off as a fledgling cult leader who is practicing his first sermons. However, the actor was not given much to work with, the whole character is but a dim imitation of Dr. Eldon Tyrell from the first Blade Runner movie. Sylvia Hoeks does a good job with what she was given, but again, it was not much: the writers resorted to the cheapest B movie trope and imply that the bad guys are bad by making them use violence as the first and only solution to every problem, and Hoeks' character was not given any nuances apart from a sadistic streak that seems odd in a machine.

Finally, there was the soundscape of the movie. This film is practically devoid of emotional music. Sounds consist mostly of thunderous rumbles and shrill synth sounds instead of real melodies; there is also a Shepard tone playing during one key scene. Absence of emotionally manipulative soundtrack is often nothing but a positive thing, but it also means that the movie has one less tool to convey and evoke feelings with. In this case, the drab and monotonous score enhances all the wrong qualities of the film.

During this movie, I kept asking myself  how many gorgeous, sweeping, flying over the city shots did this plot and story really need? 
Why were certain characters introduced for only a second or given minimal screen time instead of being emphasized as they were originally intended (they were set decoration, quite obviously!)
 There were subplots that could have been emphasized more as part of the world-building and would have been far more intriguing than some of the gratuitous relationship scenes (one scene i can understand to get a point across in world-building, but after awhile, they become excessive and obvious fluff, dragging the storytelling pace just to maximize commercial running time......)......

Please don't hate me.  So this is about a new blade runner named K (Ryan Gosling).  A lot of developments have occurred in the last thirty years since the events in the original Blade Runner, but the more things change, they're staying the same, because he's got a case to crack and replicants to track down for retiring.  Now this has been getting some pretty rave reviews, currently sitting on an 89% fresh rating on rottentomatoes.  Not only that, plenty of people are awarding this with a perfect score rating... but this is a critical darling director and a beloved property.  I went into this excited and wanting to love this.  I adore the original Blade Runner in all of its cyberpunk glory, and it saddens me to say that I never connected with this the way that I had hoped for.  Now this is not to say that this film is without merit, because that would be a falsity.  There's a whole lot to like about this, and from a technical standpoint, this is an achievement.  This is from Arrival director Denis Villeneuve, and he has style and technique for days.  The visuals are astonishing, the sound editing, design and accompanying music are standout, and the cinematography is nothing short of stellar (Roger Deakins isn't exactly a lightweight).  Blade Runner 2049 is a movie that does everything right in gathering all of the pieces that should make for a terrific movie, but all of those pieces of the puzzle never quite fit together, for me at the very least.  It works in individual scenes, but never on the whole.  It makes it very clear that it is not following the same twist of its predecessor in letting you know that K already knows that he is a replicant within the first fifteen minutes, which is something that I ended up appreciating; so many sequels just hit the same exact beats as their predecessor, so it was nice to see that not happen here.  The story sets itself up to be a commentary on the state of artificial intelligence and where it is headed in the future with the relationship with K and his software created girlfriend (Ana de Armas), and that was what I ended up being most interested in.  While it does eventually circle back around to that, you can tell very early on that this is not the main point to the story.  There are also opportunities presented to make this a discrimination story between humans and "skinjobs" as they call them, but that is dropped pretty quickly as well.  It is all really just unraveling this case which is a process in a movie that features a runtime that is already on the intimidating side.  This is a story that takes itself very seriously, and despite all of the top of the line special effects and visuals, it still feels drab because this is a world where nobody can crack a joke, never mind a smile, which is not a problem I ever had with the original.  The majority of characters in this are robots, so there is a monotone baseline that doesn't give a lot of emotional range.  I never really connected with it, and much like Mad Max: Fury Road, I found myself appreciating this more than enjoying it, despite almost every one of my peers losing their mind over a sequel that stayed true to the original property.  I can't take away from the visual flair that this features, because it is some of the most incredible eye candy you will see all year, but for me, personally, this is a beautiful movie that you can have on in the background of a party.

I had mixed feelings about seeing this movie. On the one hand, it represented a long (LONG) awaited sequel to THE most iconic cyberpunk movie ... ever. On the hand, it's a sequel almost 40 years after the fact ... of THE most iconic cyberpunk movie ... ever.

So the biggest question ... is it as good as the original? Hell no. That would have been an impossible expectation. Is it a worthy sequel? Oh yeah.

Ridley Scott and company recapture and portray a Blade Runner universe years into the future perfectly. The tone is perfectly Blade Runner, while not being a cheap knockoff. Additionally, they add perfectly to that universe with more tidbits and realities that the original movie didn't cover.

Ridley Scott's visual story telling in on huge display throughout this epic film and is a complete feast for the eyes. Ryan Gossling and Robin Wright are worthy successors to Harrison Ford and M. Emmet Walsh, while Sylvia Hoeks is on fire as the virtual intimate, Luv.

So why not 5 stars you ask? The movie drags. Two of Ridley Scott's biggest downsides are on display here; overly long and not particularly relevant cinematic pans and not knowing what to put on the cutting room floor. At two hours and forty five minutes, this movie FEELS like a long movie and that's unfortunate because it really is a great movie. But 30 to 45 minutes of this film could've easily been whacked off imo,

Having said that, great film go see it in the big theater NOW!

Blade Runner 2049 is a well-acted (thank Zeus!), slow-paced (not in a negative way) and methodical exploration into what it means to be human (which is not a novel idea, but is welcomed, yet again, in this movie). And most importantly, it's believable (or so I believe).

Written by Hampton Fancher and Michael Green
Directed by Denis Villeneuve 

The movie has a long run-time of 2 hours and 42 minutes. I'm certain this will discourage some people to watch, and others to become bored. Although the length is noticeable to a degree, but I believe it's one of the factors that makes this movie feel real and authentic. Too many movies nowadays have rushed dialogue and quick scenes which leads to leaps in continuity negatively affecting the story overall. There are many scenes here that take their time (long-takes), allowing you to take in the setting, feel its presence. I believe this is a great attribute because it helps you to be more immersed in the cinematic world being set-up and allows for characters to reveal their intricacies.

The performances, even from the supporting cast, are superb and wholly believable (which I always try to impress is THE most important factor in a movie--if you don't believe what you're watching, you won't like it [although everyone's degree of "suspension of disbelief" varies so greatly that this statement is truly subjective.... for this statement to be applied universally, I suspect most people w). However, I will say, although I love Ryan Gosling's acting I would have appreciated seeing him incorporate a few more idyisyncrasies into his character (K), but I suspect the lack thereof was indeed the point (I'm sure I will decide which is the case once I view it a second time). It was certainly a pleasure to see the nuanced acting from the cast.

Although the movie asks the much-used question "what does it mean to be Human?", it doesn't feel redundant (although I admit, I'm typically accepting of such stories no matter how many iterations we've gotten--as long as they're executed well). It's not at all heavy handed or self-righteous in any way. I would say it has a rough elegance in its exploration of the notion.

The movie's cinematography is beautiful! I had a great sense of the world through the wide, open shots of the environments the story travels through (I always believe long-takes, wide-open and vast aerial shots help construct a more believable and realized world setting). It is due to these tactics that the world the director sets up feels genuine. The environments also never felt like they were film sets, sound stages or simply staged in any sense which also speaks to the talent involved with the special effects and cgi. Like to few movies these days, the special effects and CGI is integrated perfectly, creating a beautiful world that feels one-hundred percent genuine. I left the theatre feeling as if I had watched a documentary from the future showcasing what California (and the United States for that matter) is going to be like in the future (and it's not that optimistic).


As far as the relationship between this and the first installment, I believe it seamlessly integrates so well that it appears as if  2049 is a replica of the other (in tone and vision, not to imply it's a carbon copy). I truly felt I was watching an extension of the first installment. One thing I loved about this movie is its "use" of Harrison Ford. Now, I'm not a HUGE fan of his, so I don't usually perk up for his cinematic appearances (truthfully, when I realized he was going to be in the film I thought, "Great. Another movie harping on the past by having its former star reprising"), but I thought his presence was an asset to the story (if you've seen it this is obvious) and necessary for the plot to further. I don't believe he was over-used in the slightest. 

The dialogue was also very well-written. I didn't scoff or roll my eyes during anyone's speech or "one-liner". Although I'm sure some people will disagree with me a little, as certain characters' rhythm of speech and dialogue is unconventional, that it may feel awkward at times, but I believe that is why it's successful. There are billions of us...and certainly, we do not all speak alike. 

I would say the music was at times very loud, but that may vary depending on the theatre and type of showing. The music was certainly unique and very eerie sounding, which I loved.

Overall I would say the movie was well-paced and never felt contrived. It certainly never felt rushed and you "live" long enough with Ryan Gosling's character (K) to understand who he is and what motivates him. The plot unravels at a natural and leisurely pace and I never found myself asking why in the hell a character did "XYZ". All the character's motivations were clear and reasonable enough to logically progress the film in an organic way.

This is certainly the type of film you can watch over and over, catching all the subtleties you missed in the first viewing. There is so much to appreciate about this movie. I will certainly be buying this Blu-ray.

Blade Runner 2049

Okay, my thoughts on Blade Runner 2049.  Spoilers are in the lower part of the text so if you are avoiding spoilers, don't read.  :)

Non-Spoiler Review:  An excellent movie. The imagery was just astounding.  The direction and cinematography were perfect though they don't match the look and feel of the original in every way, which is a little off-putting if you've just seen the original before watching 2049.  
The acting *much* better than what you see in the 1982 original.  God knows Harrison Ford hasn't emoted so much in any role in the last 30 years. And Gosling was outstanding; I really don't get the reservations so many people seemed to have when it was announced he was going to be starring.  Ana de Armas (Joi) was wonderful. Robin Wright played Robin Wright excellently as always. 

I felt Jared Leto was a weak link in the cast. And I say that as someone who really liked his Joker in Suicide Squad.  And given how (over)used he was this is a real problem with the movie. Sadly, Sylvia Hoeks (Luv) is no Rutger Hauer (assuming she was intended to take that role, which isn't necessarily so and that also is a problem). More on my thoughts about the antagonist(s) below in the Spoilery Comments.

There was, thankfully, no sexual assault/rape scene passed off as a seduction like there was in the original.  -.-  

2049 falls short of the original Blade Runner in several categories. But comparing it to the original is a really high bar. It's no shame that it falls a bit short. That still makes it one hell of a good movie.

I give it a 9/10 and would absolutely recommend it.  Go see it at the big screen. The bigger the better.

*******************************

Spoilery comments:

Hmm.  Okay, I liked it a lot.  So I'll just mention the things I *didn't* like and you can assume I liked everything else. :)

1.  The soundtrack isn't anywhere near the original genius work of Vangelis.  It's okay. But that's all it is.  There's not *one* single tune in the entire movie I can think of.  It's all generic background movie music. It could have been the soundtrack to any sci-fi movie. That makes it a disappointment considering how awesome the original soundtrack was and how impactful it was as part of the movie.

2.  The lack of a great antagonist really hurts the movie in comparison to the original. There flat out isn't any character that's the equivalent of Roy Batty.  There's not even a character that's written to try to be this movie's Roy. That hurts the movie a lot.  I could go on about this problem but I think I've made my point. 

3.  For that matter there isn't even an antagonist that's the equal of Pris (Daryl Hannah).  I will give full props to Dave Bautista in his small role as a old style Tyrrell Replicant. Though if I'd not watched the 10 minute short feature with his character in it before watching 2049 I don't know that I'd have cared nearly as much about his character or his scene. And that's a problem.

4.  Jared Leto plays a character that's the equivalent of the original movie's Dr. Eldon Tyrrell.  Yet Leto gets as much screen time and dialogue as Rutger Hauer's Roy.
Why? 

Leto's Niander Wallace isn't the character who Roy Batty was. He's more or less the antagonist of 2049 but they do a poor job of establishing his motivations or even his goals. Not impossible to figure out what he's doing but it's not real clear. It was extremely clear what the antagonists of the original movie were after.  It's not so clear what Wallace is doing and if he IS the primary antagonist we're left with absolutely no closure with him. The end of the movie happens and it feels like Luv was the primary antagonist. And there's even less development of her motivations and goals. 

So, yeah, they did a really weak job of presenting an antagonist to drive the conflict that drives the plot. Even Robin Wright seems like the antagonist for a while.  This is the biggest flaw in the movie imo.

5.  The plot is okay, but only okay. It suffers in comparison to the original, which was an exceptionally simple linear plot, which was why it worked.

The plot of this movie ends up being (and keep in mind that the audience doesn't even know that this is the plot until two hours of the movie have elapsed):

"Some people are hunting down Deckard because he can maybe lead them to his daughter he had with Rachel, who was a Replicant. That she gave birth and was a Tyrrell Replicant is a really big deal so some people really want to find the kid and some other people, mostly Replicants, want to keep her hidden for unclear reasons."

That just doesn't work nearly as well as Blade Runner's plot did imo.  And, again, that it's not clear that this is the plot until over 2 hours of the movie have gone by doesn't help.  For most of the movie the plot seems to be:

"Agent K, a character study, and him investigating something mysterious.  We know it's mysterious because we're told that it's mysterious."

The plot doesn't suck. But it isn't what it should have been imo.  And I easily imagine many people walked out without the ability to summarize the plot of the movie and imo that's not a good thing. Novels are great for oblique stories. Movies are less than 3 hours. It's a good idea to go with a straightforward, simple, plot.

6.  The relationship between Officer K and Joi was an excellent part of the movie. So I've got a GIANT wtf with them just killing her off and basically that's it? One little bit about her in the third act, practically at the denouement of the film, but nothing else??

I was *quite* disappointed in how her and K's story was handled by the end of the second act. By the time they leave Vegas that's IT for their story minus the one short bit near the end.

I was not pleased by this.

*******************************

Well, that's the low points I think. Like I said I liked the movie. But... I might have enjoyed it just as much if it had been 2 hours of non-storytelling clips of 2049 LA and the other sets with the actors walking around emoting things plus the soundtrack.

And that's something of a problem if you ask me.
Now that's how you make a sequel. It's both linking up to the original and telling its own story. Sweet.
beautiful cinematography, brilliant sound, but so slow. painfully slow. my 16 year old son's first words as the credits rolled was, that was depressing. he meant slow.

Superb sequel to the science fiction classic that might just be as good as the original.  The cast is excellent across the board, with Ryan Gosling's stoic lead performance anchoring the movie as K, while getting fantastic support from the rest of the cast.  Ana de Armas is heartbreaking is a role you just have to see, while Harrison Ford gives the film the perfect level of gravitas when he finally appears.  Behind the camera, director Denis Villeneuve makes a love letter to the original film, with beautiful shots showing off the dystopian future while further exploring what it means to be human.  The film even technically improves on the original in that the story is easy to follow in it just starting out as a straight detective story.  It is long at 2 hours & 44 minutes, but you never feel it as every shot is intoxicating.  The only downside is somewhat anti-climatic ending, though it ends with the perfect emotional punch, making a film that is quite possibly the equal to the original, if not better.  Time will tell on that, but so far, this is already the best film of 2017, at the very least.

Blade Runner is one of my all-time favourite movies. I've loved it since my first viewing and I had very high hopes for 2049 and the movie delivered on every level. The plot was kept a secret from every single trailer and even the reviewers were asked not to reveal anything about the plot. But, I do plan on talking about the movie in detail, so I will put a SPOILER alert right here at the start. Only read further if you've watched the movie. Here we go. The plot revolves around a blade runner who goes by the name K. He's a new "breed" of replicants which have a normal life-span and his job is to hunt down older versions of replicants and "retire" them. In the beginning we see him do just that with Sapper. Sapper was introduced back in 2036: Nexus Dawn, a short movie released before 2049. He's an old version of a replicant, he even fought on Calantha, and must therefore be retired, killed. Upon investigating around his house, K finds a buried locker. In the locker, there are bones of a replicant who gave birth. A lot of people thought this movie was going to focus on Deckard, but the real focus of the movie is actually his child. The remains found in the locker are actually that of Rachel, from the original Blade Runner. This sets off K on a dangerous and important investigation. Since the first movie never actually revealed Deckard as a replicant, I was a bit afraid this sequel was going to tell us if he is or isn't one, which would ruin the 35 year old mystery. Thankfully, we're, again, not given a straight answer! Some might be really frustrated by that, though. Tyrell Corp. is also gone, as seen in the Black Out 2022 short anime movie, and a new mastermind replaced Tyrell. Wallace, played perfectly by Jared Leto, is a new breeder of replicants who considers them his children, angels. He doesn't have a lot of screentime and he doesn't actually do much in the movie, but his presence was always intense and his dialogue is very thought-provoking, especially during the scene where we witness a birth of a replicant. Wallace Corp. also looks breathtakingly beautiful! The whole structure of the building is made to look like a pyramid and the inside is fully golden yellow/black. The main "meeting room" where Wallace always has talks with his angel Luv and, later, with Deckard, is extraordinary. The light is always moving in a circle and the shadows keep changing as the light moves. It's extremely hard to explain this, but if you've seen the movie then you know what I'm talking about. It's gorgeous. The archives, also in Wallace Corp., look breathtaking. I adore every single shot that takes place in that building. Ryan Gosling plays K, a replicant blade runner, perfectly! My favourite scene with him was when he was looking for the child in an orphanage. To add some context here, every replicant has a certain memory implanted in him to make him seem more human. K only remembers one thing. As a child, he had a wooden horse toy with something imprinted on the back of it and some kids wanted to take it away from him so he ran from them and hid the toy in one of the broken furnaces. As K is looking for information about the child in the orphanage, he realizes this is the place that he remembers as a child. After a few minutes of exploring, he actually finds the wooden horse hidden in the furnace which leads to a very devastating scene accompanied by one of the soundtrack's best tracks. It's a very haunting scene because this makes K think that he is that child and being that child will only bring him sadness as he will be hunted for the rest of his life. He realizes the danger of it and breaks down. It was truly heart-wrenching. Another scene that mesmerized me just like this one did was the one where he goes to a woman who makes these memories to see if his memory is real. She takes a look at his memory and tears start coming down her face as K sits there with zero movement, only his eyes getting watery and red. She says that someone did live this memory and that it's real. K, again, breaks down and the emotions that his character was feeling were so well potrayed by Gosling that I'm not even going to be surprised if he gets nominated for an Oscar this year. Harrison Ford reprised his role of Rick Deckard in 2049. The introduction to his character was glorious! Again, the visual style of the place where Deckard lives was out of this world. I can't praise the movie enough regarding the direction and cinematography. I'm not going to say anything about Deckard and what he does in this movie because I really do not want to spoil anything regarding his story. I'll just say that it was very emotional and very satisfying. The ending, especially, was beautifully realized. I'm in awe at how perfectly everything concluded. The CGI is wonderful! Nothing ever looked fake, not one single thing. Everything looked unusually realistic and there were times where I just stared at the screen without even realising I haven't blinked for minutes. The soundtrack by Hans Zimmer and  Benjamin Wallfisch is a bliss. It's very reminiscent of the Vangelis soundtrack for Blade Runner and it was perfect! I got goosebumps every single time that deep synth kicked in. It's most certainly best experienced in a cinema, though. I can't wait for this movie to come out on blu-ray so I can watch it again and again and again. All in all, Blade Runner 2049 is a phenomenal movie that completely blew me away and I couldn't recommend seeing this movie more. Truly one of a kind movie and something you don't see very often coming to cinemas. It's basically a 200 million dollar art movie and with its epic length of 2 hours and 40 minutes, I was surprised at how short it actually was! I think a lot of "mainstream" audiences will dislike this movie for being boring, long and not action-heavy. As soon as I walked out of the cinema, I could hear a woman behind me saying how she slept through half of the movie. It makes me feel kind of sad that extraordinary movies, like this one, get hated on so much by casual moviegoers. Oh well, just got to get used to that. Still, 2049 is currently the movie of the year for me and I couldn't be happier with it.

The impact sounds of the high intensity scenes made each bullet shot sound deliberate and powerful, and the scenes that were crafted for build up used very particular tones that would make your whole body tingle... This is definitely a contender for best score, but direction was also equally amazing. The visuals live up to the story as Villeneuve  lives up to the same Noir style from the original Blade Runner, but brings his own impact as some scenes lacked colour purposefully other scenes were so color filled you could feel as if your were staring into a neon light. I write this as unseasonal rain and thunderstorms make my window panes shudder.
Human beings should probably be called just 'beings'. We aren't human, if the two Blade Runner movies are anything to go by.
As is always the case with Denis Villeneuve films, this isn't your run-of-the-mill pewpew sci-fi extravaganza. It's a meditative experience. A lot of sci-fi films tend to show Artificial Intelligence as the 'evil side' - they're mostly black-and-white stereotypes. Not in the Blade Runner universe. The best part is you cannot compare Part 1 with 2 - they both stand together as one. Villeneuve, along with Deakins and Zimmer/Wallfisch, ensure that we don't have to leave the Scott/Vangelis/Cronenworth universe even while enjoying a new tale.
The story in a nutshell - K (Ryan Gosling) is a Blade Runner. But he's also a new breed of 'replicant', a bioengineered human being designed to only obey orders. His task is to seek out older replicants gone rogue, and to 'retire' (read: terminate) them. Along the way, he has to deal with the enigmatic new head of the Tyrell Corporation, Niander Wallace (Jared Leto) and his replicant enforcer Luv (whose hairstyle matches Rachel, Tyrell's replicant and Deckard's lover). He also has to deal with 'Madam' Lt. Joshi (Robin Wright). To keep him company at home is an Artificial Intelligence who goes by the name 'Joi' (played by the gorgeous Ana de Armas). K happens to discover a secret that could shake the very foundation of the world they're living in - and that forms the basis of the plot. Watch the film to get the rest, I implore you.
While there are obvious nods to the original, the beauty lies in the way Villeneuve has chosen to execute those exact moments. There is a beautiful rendition of 'Tears in Rain' at some point in the film that, while not as powerful as the original, will certainly make you shed a tear or two. There is also a slightly left-field reference to Philip K Dick's novel, but I'll leave that for you to find out.
To allow us to fully grasp the meaning of such easter eggs and the themes, the screenplay by Hampton Fancher and Michael Green moves at a leisurely pace. The comparisons to Tarkovsky weren't unfounded - there are quite a few long, silent takes (Deakins is your best friend here, he makes the whole film look like a bloody work of art - you barely feel the length of the takes), almost as if Villeneuve wants to you understand the impact of the moment, and the decisions of the characters, before moving on to the next scene. There are important questions about what humanity is, and what the value of a memory is - things that we, in the real world, often take for granted. That's where we realise the difference between the non-human and human elements in the film - it's almost as if they've exchanged ideologies. The film will make you wonder at the end - what does humanity mean? And are all humans necessarily humane?
The end is the real clincher for me. In the original Blade Runner, the film ends with Roy Batty (Rutger Hauer) standing in the rain, giving one of the most powerful soliloquies in the world (Tears in Rain). It's symbolic, because all he wanted was to live a human life, and because he's dying, those beautiful memories of his will be lost in the rain. The world is broken, and Deckard and Rachel are on the run from an uncertain future. In this film, Ryan Gosling is shown sleeping under snowfall - snowflakes are falling on his face, while Deckard goes to meet someone very special. The raindrops have solidified and become snowflakes - the world is (hopefully) a happier place, and Deckard finally gets to piece his broken past together. No more memories will be lost in the rain, now that the rain is solidified.
I was in a daze the moment I stepped out of the theatre. I needed to sit down, pause and reflect on life. Blade Runner 2049 is a new-age sci-fi classic with traditional values that hits you hard the more you think about it. Villeneuve has given Ridley Scott a glorious tribute, and expanded a much-loved universe with more love. It's a film you have to see to believe.

Blade Runner 2049 is an art house sci-fi epic  given a 200 million budget and 
full creative control. It fell under the right hands to tackle an extremely difficult task - creating a sequel to what is already a masterpiece. They managed to pull off a sequel of at least equal standing with the original.

The visuals gave me the revolutionary sense of what it was like to watch Blade Runner when it was first released in 1982. Using a combination of CG and practical effects, every frame was a painting. The colorful artificial lights contrasting with the grayness of the chaotic, decaying ecosystem gave me a sense of desolation and hopelessness making the very real human moments all the more powerful. Although a distinct movie from the original, the sequel expands on the sci-fi world building of the original as well as its themes, the main one being, what does it mean to be human?

The movie is confident with its pacing, never pandering or losing focus on its path to pure sci-fi greatness. If I were to be nitpicky, the only slight flaw I found was one or two scenes that could have been shortened or entirely cut.

It may not do well in the box office like most art house movies, but like the original, it will be remembered as one of the sci-fi greats for many decades to come.
