There is much to like about this highly-anticipated sequel to Ridley Scott's 1982 neo-noir science fiction classic. Ryan Gosling dusts off that sleepy-eyed, low-octane acting style of earlier roles to great effect as K, a replicant blade runner tasked with unraveling a game-changing mystery that links him with his predecessor Rick Deckard (a feisty Harrison Ford, who's seemingly on a mission to revive all of his past movie characters...can 'Regarding Henry 2' be far behind?). For his part, director Denis Villeneuve ('Sicario', 'Arrival') faithfully evokes the original film's dystopian setting with stunning visuals and a thunderous, bone-chilling score that will transport you right back to those grimy Los Angeles streets of the future.

That being said, the very elements that made Scott's movie aesthetically ground-breaking have been duplicated so often over the thirty-five years that separate these two films that they can't help but feel a little underwhelming this time around. Worse, the movie's languid pacing will make you feel every one of its 163 minutes, which makes its thin plotting and underdeveloped themes all the more frustrating. [Some may argue that the original film shares this same lack of narrative depth, but at least it wrapped things up in under two hours.] Sure, the shadowy figures that populate BLADE RUNNER 2049 do a good deal of soul-searching, but to little avail. This long-awaited trip 'back to the future' is an interesting misfire, but a misfire all the same.

To say it's a slow burner is putting it mildly. 49, trying to match the noir aspects of the first film, forgets at times that atmosphere is essential to noir and not just slow pacing. (The drawn-out fight scene at the end to justify a climax, for example.) The sanitary brightly lit LAPD station also harms the noir aesthetic and other jumps in location expand the world but at a loss of overall plot structure and cohesive vision. At times it felt like I was watching parts of a TV series crammed together hoping it will all make a nearly 3-hour long movie. The performances were top notch, but the characters themselves and their needlessly dense dialogue were what bogged down what could have been good scenes. (Side note, Harrison Ford gave a better performance with half the effort of Jared Leto) But seriously tho, Jared Leto's monologs only confused the motivation of his character. (Maybe it takes so long to make replicants because you have to give a speech before killing them for no reason? IDK) The production design was pretty but one dimensional. what made the original so visually striking was the film grain and the miniatures and the set dressing, things lacking in this rebootquel.  In all, 2049 is a rather convoluted attempt to rebrand another 80s classic and I hope they don't make another one. I'll take a Neuromancer adaptation instead.

Blade Runner 2049 is the highly anticipated sequel to the 1982 classic that changed how we looked the sci-fi genre & it is well worth the wait! For the past thirty years, the human race has been integrated with bioengineered humans called replicants. One of the newly formulated replicants is K (Ryan Gosling) a Blade Runner for the LAPD. Ks job is to track & retire the problematic outdated replicants still at large. After being sent on a routine mission to retire Sapper Morton (Dave Bautista), an outdated replicant quietly living as a protein farmer, K discovers human remains inside a box buried beneath a long dead tree. When forensic examination reveals that the 30-year-old remains are from a female replicant, Rachael, who apparently died giving birth to a child from her union with human Blade Runner Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford), the search begins for this evolutionary anomaly. LAPD is intent on finding & terminating the hybrid replicant while replicant manufacturer Niander Wallace (Jared Leto) sends his sadistic enforcer Luv (Sylvia Hoeks) to track down the human-replicant in order to further endow his future replicants. As K investigates the identity of Rachael & Deckards child, he begins to question whether his memories are the just the usual implants or perhaps actually his real experiences. Blade Runner 2049 is directed by Denis Villeneuve from the screenplay by Michael Green & Hampton Fancher, wrote the screenplay for the first film. Blade Runner 2049 is a CINEMATIC MASTERPIECE; a mesmerizing immersion into an alternate reality that is exquisitely haunting & emotionally charged. This is a sci-fi film that has all the same captivating elements of the first film & so much more depth & impact. The visual effects were awe-inspiring & have you believing that this world could actual exist. The performances from the cast also feature Robin Wright as Ks boss, Lieutenant Joshi, Carla Juri as Dr. Ana Stelline, & Ana de Armas as Ks hologram companion Joi, were all excellent. Ryan Gosling gives one of the best performances of his career & should get some major Best Actor award consideration. I highly recommend watching the first film to fully understand the storyline & also to appreciate the technical elements used in the 80s compared to todays filming style. Blade Runner 2049 is a film that youll want to see again. Blade Runner 2049 is a GIGANTIC MUST-SEE FILM OF THE YEAR which you can experience in 2D, 3D or IMAX 3D.

Blade Runner 2049 seamlessly fuses poetic visuals with a timely set of themes while taking its time in allowing each scene to breathe. This is the kind of sequel to a classic film that brings the series into the modern day without sacrificing what gave the original its identify to begin with.

If you loved the original, then you'll appreciate this remake that's clearly more a labor of love than an attempt to cash in. Amazingly BR 2049 really feels like Blade Runner. Painstaking effort was put into creating an atmosphere that's ominous and bleak yet beautiful. The characters are well developed, including those even more synthetic than the replicants. Interestingly, there's a form of classism among the myriad synthetic life forms. To say I wouldn't have liked this if it were bad would be a lie. You can't really have a conversation about it without placing it in context of the preceding film from 1982 (or, really, 2007's The Final Cut) and Philip K. Dick's original book Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep? that will both forever serve as monoliths of science fiction. When trying to analyse it completely separate from the first film, 2049 just doesn't hold up, so it is much more a companion piece in terms of plot with a few updated themes. At the base of the film, the central performances are quite strong. You have a career best for Harrison Ford. Gosling brings more of his Drive strong, silent, and violent repose. The supporting roles from namely Sylvia Hoeks and Ana de Armas are fitting, and even Jared Leto manages to inject real some gravitas into his megalomaniac villain.

Visually, there really isn't anything better out there. The production design is absolutely epic. Roger Deakins' signature cinematography effortlessly blends the ambition of 2001: A Space Odyssey with the vastness of the west he showcased in the Coens' No Country for Old Men and his previous outing with director Denis Villeneuve Sicario. For a sound meets visual experience, you could not ask for more, as even the occasionally farty, but very Hans Zimmer score mitigates the expectations set by Vangelis' original themes.

My initial reaction to the story was one of disappointment. While fulfilling the neo-noir genre with a somewhat convoluted crime mystery there are few thin points in the plot, but noir is about atmosphere, and this one has that in droves. What at first seemed like pointless CG eddies filled with adolescent techno-sex fantasies end up becoming footnotes on Gosling's inner struggle - rectifying his replicant nature with his desire to be or feel human. Throw in the fact that he is in love with a hologram woman projected by his phone, and you can fill in the gaps about what that suggests of modern living.

At two and a half hours, there are so many thematic elements embodied by the different characters that it would be a chore to list them all, but as with any Villeneuve film, that richness is understated and takes a back seat to the visuals and action. As to whether you will be satisfied with it leaving the theater, I think it will depend on how much import you place on the source material and what you have come to expect from the blockbuster experience. In the case of the former, I would say Blade Runner 2049 falls a bit short. In the latter, of course, it far surpasses anything in the past few years.

Deciding to film a sequel for "Blade Runner" is a lot like being Bob Dylan's son and deciding you're gonna follow in the old man's footsteps and become a musician: there's no way to live up to the impossible expectations created by the greatness of the original. 

And like the Wallflowers before them, Denis Villeneuve & Co have gamely made a solid effort, yet for all their determination wind up feeling like imitators rather than innovators. And not just imitators of the original film--that is to be expected. No, where the original film created a unique neo-noir dystopia that brought the idiosyncratic genius of Philip K. Dick to life, "Blade Runner 2049" feels more like an exercise in checking off by-now-common science fiction tropes, tropes that have been explored far more successfully by other recent films/TV (Ex Machina, Battlestar Galactica, Mad Max: Fury Road, etc).

While not breaking new ground, the first 2/3 of "2049" was engaging and engrossing: the attention to detail in the world-building was superb, and the performances by Ryan Gosling, Robin Wright, & Co were solid, if not great. Things then, sadly, fall apart in the third act, where it seems to me that Villeneuve, Hampton Fancher & Co tacked on an ending from a different film: a generic, action-oriented denouement of schmaltz, parenthood, and "revolution". 

It's as though they forgot what it was that made the original "Blade Runner" so successful in the first place: it's a noir procedural; the characters and their problems are small scale, and their actions don't really effect their world. Replicants escape from time to time, and they have to be hunted down; it's a job, it's housecleaning. That some of the replicants (like Roy Batty) are more human than their human creators is ultimately irrelevant to everyone except for Deckard, whose view only changes when confronted by Batty's act of mercy and his naked, frightened, human mortality at the very end.

In "2049", the procedural elements are compelling; but when those are jettisoned in the third act, the jarring shift in tone brings everything crashing down. Tired messianic themes and "Terminator" knock-offs replace the (mostly) quiet, confident storytelling of the first two acts. I say "mostly" quiet, because someone (Ridley Scott? Villeneuve?) had the bright idea of asking Hans Zimmer to compose the score for this thing, and that score pretty much veered between garish re-workings of the score from the original "Terminator" and cynical, strategic use of glosses of Vangelis' classic score from the original "Blade Runner". 

In the final analysis, "2049" is a film of its time, for good and ill. It's okay. "Blade Runner", on the other hand, was a film so far ahead of its time and so perfectly wrought that it remains essentially timeless, holding up after countless repeat viewings. It's hard to imagine that many folks in the future will feel compelled to spend the nearly 3 hours required to revisit "2049".

Canadian director Denis Villeneuve is quietly becoming one of the most interesting and exciting filmmakers in Hollywood today. Since 2015 he has released modern masterpieces Sicario and Arrival, with this sci-fi sequel adding another triumph to his recent success. Although linked to Ridley Scott's 1982 cult classic, this futuristic epic stands on its own two feet with a new story centred on LAPD agent K (Ryan Gosling), a Blade Runner (someone who hunts and 'retires' faulty androids) questioning his own existence. With unwavering support from girlfriend Joi (Ana de Armas), K continues to seek answers in places his superiors would prefer he didn't look, all paths leading to an infamous predecessor who has been missing for 30 years: Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford). Screenwriters Hampton Fancher and Michael Green have provided Villeneuve with an abundance of meaty, thought-provoking material to bring to life, real world parables thinly veiled inside an intelligent and mature narrative that even provides a few genuinely impressive twists. Cleverly inserted flashbacks and references provides enough context for those who aren't familiar with Scott's Blade Runner, but thankfully the audience is credited with enough smarts to join the dots without having their hands held. For a movie so focussed on the theme of identity, it's only fitting that Villeneuve-along with veteran cinematographer Roger Deakins-has crafted an exquisite visual identity that pays homage to the original whilst establishing it's own uniqueness. Every frame is meticulously dressed, the stunning production design merging seamlessly with the CGI to create a utopian world that feels entirely lived-in, whether it's the metallic, technology-centric inner-city or the dusty, wasting-away outer limits. The score by Benjamin Wallfisch and Hans Zimmer is also amazing, the deep base and subtle synth tunes seeping into each scene to enhance the ethereal atmosphere. Don't be scared off by the lengthy runtime, Villeneuve ties all of the elements together-including outstanding performances from Gosling, de Armas, Robin Wright and Jared Leto-to deliver an utterly engrossing sci-fi saga that warrants a big screen viewing. Blade Runner 2049 is that rare follow-up that not only matches what came before, but surpasses it.

I can start by saying that I'm not a fan of the original.  While I can see why people like it and hold it in high regard, it was a mature science fiction movie that was a couple years before my movie going time and it never fully 'clicked' with me.  I've watched 1982's Blade Runner a few times in my adult years and, despite not being able to get all on board with it, I can still recognize it as a great sci-fi movie, just not one I am in to.  This isn't 1982 though, onto the review of Blade Runner 2049.

     Say what you want, word it how you will... Blade Runner 2049 has a style all it's own and it owns it.  Cold, dark, grim, sharp, and heavy are all words that could describe Blade Runner 2049 and none of them are necessarily bad.  'Heavy' could be the most problematic description for a movie but this is a movie that knows it's density and doesn't bother asking the audience for help and it doesn't need to.  All the wonderful premises that science fiction presents for the future of science and technology should come with the warning that is Blade Runner 2049.  If someone goes into this movie sane then they will still probably be sane when they leave BUT it could get the crazy train going for some.  If someone is already crazy going in, they're screwed.  Regardless of one's sanity, if one really sinks their teeth into this movie then they really should doubt reality and even doubt who and what they are afterwards, because... how do you know for sure?

     Crazy is good, and Blade Runner 2049 is crazier than the 'cold,' 'dark,' 'grim,' 'sharp,' and 'heavy' tags that can be applied to it to make the audience believe it's not crazy at all.  If I had to describe the type of ride it is, I would say it's like a roller coaster that is completely submerged underground.  A very dark ride that you don't know where it's headed from one turn to the next, but it never gets too high or has too steep of a drop off because of the limits it being underground presents.  I am not sure it's a 'top ten sci-fi movie of all-time' but it can make a good and strong case.

To start with the positives, I'll definitely award big points to the visuals. I may have spent half the movie looking at my watch, but what I saw up on the imax screen was impressive. It goes beyond good art direction and cinematography - all the world-building details were really interesting, so I have to applaud that. There are numerous tertiary characters sprinkled throughout the film that make the world fee truly alive. I, for one, would have loved to have spent more time with Barkhad Abdi's Dr. Badger or Lennie James' Mr. Cotton.

As for the primary cast, Sylvia Hoeks and Ana de Armas have the most interesting characters, and both display admirable screen presence that carries their scenes. Harrison Ford is only in it for the money, but does his grumpy old man schtick well enough. Robin Wright is decent as Gosling's superior, and even Dave Bautista does a good job with his small, but effective role.

Ryan Gosling, on the other hand... Well, he plays Ryan Gosling. He's in his default "blank expression" mode cultured from his time spent with Nicolas Winding Refn. For my money, Gosling is a wildly unconvincing actor. I never get the sense that he's actually the character I'm watching, only that he's Ryan Gosling playing make-believe for a paycheck. He only really shines when given good dialogue. The best Gosling performances I can remember were in Gangster Squad and The Nice Guys, because he was given things to say and do except stare off into space. He has a few good moments here, namely when playing off de Armas' character, and in a few plot-critical scenes I won't spoil, but 90% of the time you could replace him with a cardboard cutout and I wouldn't be able to tell the difference. There exist great actors who can sit in relative silence for the majority of a film, but these kinds of performances work when you have an actor who communicates great volumes of information from even the slightest facial expressions. Gosling does not have an expressive enough mug to be doing this kind of non-acting so frequently.

And then there's Jared Leto, who has made it his mission lately to give the AMPAS second thoughts about awarding him their coveted golden statuette. Whilst not giving us another Suicide Squad Joker-level performance, instead he gives us his "Blind God", a pretentious douchebag who rambles about ambition, slavery, divine creation, blah, blah, blah, none of it arriving within a mile of a salient point. Honestly, this character accomplishes nothing in the movie, and exists only to communicate one of the movie's most punishingly obvious themes. Listen, I don't know if you've ever heard this before - it's kind of a weird concept - but bear with me, ok?

Slavery? It's bad.

Did I just blow your fucking mind? No? Oh. Well, that takes the thunder out of the movie's message a little bit. BR2049 seems to be all about slavery and a coming slave revolt, except it presents it in such a ham-fisted way, it warrants more of an eye-roll than an attaboy. By the time Replicant Lives Matter showed up to recruit Gosling, the movie had bathed in graphic slave plantation imagery and splattered the cyberpunk n-word across the walls and tongues of future California. Yet despite the subtext, nothing actually comes of the (supposedly) escalating movement. This is not the only theme in the movie, but it's the one that's given the most attention. The story presents an idea that it claims will have catastrophic consequences (I'm trying to be vague to save you from spoilers), but it doesn't care about those consequences. It doesn't even explore the ideas from a philosophical perspective. Instead the shocking revelation that precipitates the central conflict is just a MacGuffin to keep the action moving along. When Denis Villeneuve's name pops up on the screen, and the auditorium lights have clicked back on, you're left with nothing.

That's my biggest problem with this movie - it's empty. It doesn't have a story, the characters don't have arcs - it's a bunch of things that happen, and then the movie ends. Yes, it's a detective story, and features the detective uncovering clues and following leads, but without a compelling character (or compelling screen presence to play the lead), everything in the movie just feels like a flat sequence of events that seem to be building up to something that never happens. This would be more excusable in a briskly-paced 90-minute movie, but not across 164 minutes.

Also, on a more minor note, whilst the visuals are great, the audio was a mixed bag. The music was sometimes effective, but too often fell into the trap of the "loud bwaaaamm" noisy synth stabs. The sound effects were also mixed very high, resulting in cacophonous explosions and gunfire, and fisticuffs that sounded like Harrison Ford was beating up Ryan Gosling with an obese salmon.

BLADE RUNNER 2049 is very much a worthy sequel to the original BLADE RUNNER.  Interestingly, the thing that makes it a worthy sequel is also its biggest weakness: the pace.  Like the original film, this movie is very slow.  Unlike the original film, however, this movie is also very long, making the slow, quiet pace seem REALLY slow and REALLY quiet.  Almost too slow, at times.  It's also chock full of extra stuff that, quite frankly, could've been left out to give it a more acceptable run-time.  Things like K's holographic girlfriend.  She's a good character and it makes for an interesting contrast since she (a virtual A.I.) actually comes off as more human than K (a replicant) does, but ultimately, she adds almost nothing to the story, and yet we spend a lot of time exploring their relationship.  And honestly, even Harrison Ford's character, Deckard, the same character from the first movie, is a bit pointless.  Like Han Solo, I got the feeling he was only there as fan-service and his presence dictates the time period (both this movie and STAR WARS THE FORCE AWAKENS had to take place 30 years later to account for Ford's age, where, otherwise, these sequels could have taken place at any point and both probably would have been better films for it).

What 2049 really gets right is returning to the world of the first movie and even managing to expand on it quite a bit.  It's a rich, iconic world and it was fun to see it again after all this time (even if it was shockingly similar to the setting of the live action GHOST IN THE SHELL...  To the point where we can almost imagine that both movies take place in the same world).  Apparently, the future of advertising is 100-stories tall holographic women walking around between buildings like sexy, translucent kaiju.

If you're a fan of the original BLADE RUNNER you won't be disappointed in 2049.  It's worth seeing in theaters for the graphics alone.  It's a seriously visual movie that really deserves the theater experience.  It earns a "Buy it on 3-D Blu-Ray" on Talon's Movie Scale.

Unless you're living under a rock, you're aware that we currently live in an era where nostalgia and reboots are at an all-time high. With a few exceptions, most attempts have fallen flat on their face (Point Break? Fuller House anyone?). With unpolished cultural properties slowly running out, I suppose it was only a matter of time before Blade Runner was targeted for a reboot. When hardcore fans (myself included) first heard about this, there were more gulps than cheers. After all, Blade Runner's stature is unique. It landed with a thud back in 1982, but it's legacy has swelled like a balloon ever since. After being re-cut twice (the 2007 final cut is my personal fav) only now is it regarded as the masterpiece it always deserved to be. And let's face it, it never cried out for a sequel (neither version, that is). Alas, here we are with Blade Runner 2049 helmed by French-Canadian director Denis Villenueve (Arrival, Sicario, Prisoners) and produced by original director Ridley Scott. So...how'd they do?

Well, first off, this flick is PACKED with spoilers. That being said, you're only getting an opinion here. Blade Runner 2049 steps out of the shadow of it's predecessor and emerges a towering colossus. It's one of the best sequels ever made and one of the best science fiction movies I've ever seen in my life. Yep, we're in that rare company of sequels here that equals, if not exceeds the first. Ryan Gosling is wonderful in the lead, Harrison Ford hasn't been THIS good since The Fugitive and both newcomers Ana de Armas and Sylvia Hoeks are stars in the making (de Armas, especially, is heartbreaking). Jared Leto is predictably obnoxious, which might actually be a brilliant sleight-of-hand casting trick here since he's the villain. Within the first 15 minutes alone, it's plain to see why Ridley Scott hand-picked Villenueve to helm this incredible film. It's easily the most vital sci-fi movie released by the majors since District 9. Blade Runner fans won't believe their eyes and ears when the house lights go up...if they aren't busy DRYING their eyes, that is. It's stunning. Simply stunning.

It made no sense to bring Harrison Ford back. His story arc at the end of the first movie was complete. Shoehorning him and Sean Young into the movie was forced and desperate. Rick Deckard is not an integral part of the Blade Runner universe. Just because a character is important to us does not make him the center of the Blade Runner world. Also, Blade Runner is not about freedom, it's about what it means to be human. This pale sequel attempts to answer the question of what makes one human by saying that dying for a cause makes someone human. Ignoring how that makes no sense, that goes against the themes of the original. The original was also clever and ambiguous about whether or not replicants were people or just machines and whether or not Blade Runners were murderers or just retiring unneeded technology. This movie lacks the subtlety and grace of the original by insulting its audience by saying "Fuck it, replicants are an unobvious metaphor for an oppressed minority and Blade Runners are fugitive slavers. Can't let the audience be confused." Another problem with bringing Deckard back is that he doesn't have much of an identity outside of Ford's acting persona (playing tough but vulnerable men). Obviously Ford's approach to that has changed in 40 years so when he plays Deckard again, he doesn't seem like Deckard, he just seems like old Harrison Ford. It's not like when he returned to the role of Indiana Jones or Han Solo where, like those movies or not, he actually did feel like an older version of those characters. Why? Because those characters were better established than Deckard, who was clearly not intended to be the protagonist of an entire franchise, let alone meant to return 40 years later for an unnecessary sequel. Ford aside, the acting was terrible. Gosling was wooden, Jared Leto was just embarrassingly bad, Robin Wright was clearly just there for the paycheck, etc. All the characters were also incredibly bland. Most disappointing of all was Luv, a very, very poor replacement for Roy Batty who had no personality outside of being the tough "bad girl". Having pretty lights does not automatically make a movie good. Looking "purty" does not make up for a terrible script and terrible acting. I haven't seen any of Villenue's other work and after this I am in no hurry. The emperor has no clothes.

I remember sneering at the idea of a sequel to Ridley Scott's Blade Runner, thinking about what would be the point apart from making a quick buck and ruining an absolute masterpiece in the process. Villeneuve understood the pressure and responsibility he would have to take on and was initially set against the idea until reading the script, hearing Harrison Ford was already on board and Ridley Scott was in the executive producer's chair. Sean Young and Rutger Hauer have previously commented negatively towards the idea of the sequel with Young actually suggesting a boycott should she not be involved and Hauer, sharing my sentiments, could not understand the reasons of creating a sequel of something that he already considers cinematic perfection. 

My reservations eventually turned into expectations being fully aware of having some of the most amazingly talented people in the business being on board in the production. Villeneuve's regular, amazing cinematographer, Roger Deakins is here, Hans Zimmer and Benjamin Wallfisch on the score and Blade Runner's screenwriter Hampton Fancher returns to write the story and screenplay. But it is really just Hollywood attaching key names to ensure the ticket sales? 

Scott's Blade Runner was such a masterpiece in every sense giving rise to neo-noir science-fiction which had an outstanding score, a simplistic yet provoking story, the alluring performances with an enchanting production of artistic perfection that made a futuristic world look seemingly dated. It's all of these key elements that I had reservations about, wondering how Villeneuve and Co. would attempt to continue the story 35 years on. 

It's set 30 years on from Blade Runner's 2019 and whilst we see a much larger world here, it's still very much a world that remains stagnant with the only key advancement we see are those of the latest replicants, the model Nexus-8s. "K", our new Blade Runner is on the prowl, but while retiring a formidable "skinjob" he discovers an incredible revelation that could change the world and rouses his imagination and questions his loyalties. 

The story is smart enough to engage most, but it does seem to slip towards to end, like it struggles to reach an inevitable conclusion. You think it's becoming predictable but there's enough twists and subplot interventions to keep the intrigue going, even with the drawn out runtime that doesn't aid in creating anticipation leaving audiences hanging for longer than necessary. 

I was initially excited by the 163minute running time, but now having seen it, It's too long where it probably didn't need to be, where the pacing is incredibly slow and almost every scene is drawn out with long pauses of silence to parade Villeneuve's obvious, artful flair. It's a Villeneuve's film alright, set in a Blade Runner world but they should have heeded Dr. Eldon Tyrell's statement about the candle burning twice as bright and made this half as long. Well, not half as long but you get the metaphor. 

The part was written with Gosling in mind and he suited the role of "K" with his usual stone-faced and often emotionless persona. I could see pass the Gosling I knew, empathising with his character. It was Deckard I had trouble with. All I could see was Harrison Ford and even with him standing there, I could almost forget the Deckard I was familiar with. Let's not forget, Deckard is only here not because he "was good" at what he did, because, in truth he wasn't anything but lucky; he's here by the grace of Roy Barry's sudden change of heart and mercifully letting him live. I can't be precise, but there's something different, and yes I get the character, as well as the actor has aged, but there's a part of me that thinks Harrison had forgotten how to play Deckard. 

I'm not entirely sure of the purpose of the character Joi, who's name might be a direct reference to the pornographic world, other than to increase some emotion investment for "K". Ana de Armas is stunning and adorable at the same time, but I think you could cut her entirely from the story and it wouldn't make that much of a difference. The character I really enjoyed beside Gosling's "K" was Sylvia Hoeks' Luv. A ruthless femme fatale who is more than just an assistant to replicant godlike creator, Niander Warren who's played poetically by Jared Leto. I feel there's a lot more to both their stories than what the film and the shorts let on. 

Whilst it does answer a lot of unanswered questions of the first film, mainly, is Deckard a replicant? It does provoke it's own set of questions flipping the quandary back and forth, affording replicants the freedom of imagination often being a sad reality and actually represents humanity's own desire to feel special, wanting to be the chosen one. There's a pang of betrayal but with no-one to truly blame, and there's a personal realisation of just how insignificant we can be in the grand scheme of things. And like the first film, it ends on an opportunity, leaving the door open for possibly more. Where does mankind go after this? What happens next? Which side will you be on? 

The production as a whole is very impressive keeping much to the fashion of Blade Runner. The verbally-controlled analytical equipment, the costumes, the constant downpour, the oversized decanters and a possibly synthetic pet which might be a nod to Philip K. Dick's original story of Deckard wanting a real pet to elevate his status. Other little touches was the etched symbolic date that echoes the US general release and the neon multimedia advertising with some obvious major corporations waving their Illuminated banners. Did anyone else frown at the possible patriotic product placement? Peugeot? Really? 

The marketing and promotion has been the best I've seen this year, with 3 shorts being released periodically prior to the main film coming out. It has to be mentioned here, Luke Scott, son of Ridley Scott directed two segments, "Nexus Dawn" 2036 and "Nowhere to Run" 2048 with Cowboy Bebop creator Shinichirô Watanabe creating an anime short Blade Runner 2022 "Black Out". All being very impressive and intriguing. However, I was quite surprised there was no additional screening of Scott's original masterpiece, like what Scott did with Alien: Covenant showing Alien and Prometheus just prior to Covenant's release. But, I think I now understand why. It might be because of the contrast of style, character and tone would be more noticeable? 

Benjamin Wallfisch and Hans Zimmer composed the score and sadly I think they have missed a trick here. However it does suit and makes this very much a Villeneuve film but personally, I wanted to see and hear a Blade Runner film and was hoping for the same ingenuity Vangelis created for the first. Listening to the score in isolation, I can't deny it's superb quality, but it's a score for an entire film, unlike Vangelis' individuality of an unique score. This isn't unique and much like the film, it's an inspired piece with parts borrowed from Vangelis'; some more obvious than others, with one key scene that almost attempts to rob off the original but I understand it to be a cue for the fans. Some parts have even been recycled from Dunkirk, just minus the tick-tocking. I also found the use of tracks from Elvis and Sinatra off-putting and unnecessary. There must have been a conscious choice and reasoning over the decided tracks and I'm thinking there was an opportunity to use something from today's musical arena, being from their past but making the film more relatable. 

In comparison, this one lacks character, has a disparity from the previous and doesn't have the same magic of making a futuristic world seem old, distancing itself from Blade Runner's dismal Los Angeles. But don't get me wrong, the direction is nothing short of spectacular, the tonal style of this film differs greatly from Blade Runner allowing more colour to seep in and this isn't a criticism. The balance has been tilted offering predominantly daytime scenes as oppose to the dark, wet nights of Blade Runner; and the deployment of light, shadow and a full spectrum of colour is used so incredibly well, creating a vast range of artistic scenes and sequences. 

For me, sequel versus previous; this is a perfect example of the previous being the trend-setter, the original that made neo-noir a genre, the one that inspires and continues to do so, where as this, the sequel is clearly the inspired, setting no aspirations or bringing anything original. To quote Salvador Dalí "A true artist is not one who is inspired, but one who inspires others." Which ultimately results in this being a stunning Villeneuve imagining of an already established fantasy.

Three decades after Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford), a former "Blade Runner" cop assigned to hunt down the human-like robots known as "Replicants" vanished without a trace, a new Blade Runner known as Officer K (Ryan Gosling)discovers a horrifying secret about his past buried deep within the depths of Los Angeles...

Aside from the original Alien, and despite the fact that it failed to make a profit on it's original release due to both constant meddling from executives and the fact that most audiences at the time didn't get it's more complex themes, Blade Runner,thanks to multiple director's cuts and re-airings on TV, has become one of the most important sci-fi films in history with it's visual style being the basis of the rise of the cyberpunk genre with films such as The Matrix and Ghost in the Shell.

Although it's highly debatable whether or not this long-awaited sequel is as good as Ridley Scott's magnum opus, Blade Runner 2049 does manage to recapture the awe and spectacle of the groundbreaking design of the futuristic America thanks to the outstanding cinematography, as expected from the likes of the great Roger Deakins, and the use of the colour schemes does manage to make this dirty polluted world look incredible, even in a post Mad Max: Fury Road world.

Speaking of that film, like Fury Road, 
the score and the visuals is what sets this film apart from any other film this year. 

Although the plot itself does feel dragged out at times due to the long running time of two hours and forty-three minutes, both writers including the original screenwriter of the first film Hampton Fancher and Michael Green add enough twists and turns in the narrative and thankfully keep it unpredictable enough to match the uncomfortable environment of the original film.

Ryan Gosling does an impressive job as the (not a spoiler by the way as it's established in the first five minutes) Replicant Blade Runner Officer K and although his arc isn't as strong as Rick's, his arc does go down some impressive twists. Speaking of Rick Deckard himself, even if the character isn't in the film for as much as the marketing is leading you to believe, Harrison Ford, once again steals the show with his talent of bringing new dimensions to his most famous characters being on full display here. However the best performance comes from newcomer Ana de Armas as K's sweet hologram wife Joi. Once again in keeping with the themes of artificial intelligence wanting to be human, her sweet nature and her devotion to K humanises the bleak tone of this film, much like how Sean Young's Rachael brought humanity to the Replicant race in the first film.

Overall, despite having a few problems in it's script such as Jered Leto's underdeveloped antagonist, Denis Villeneuve has managed to craft a worthy companion piece to the 1982 classic. As mentioned before, it's debatable which one is better in the overall long-run, but Blade Runner 2049 will serve as proof  that the legacy of the original film is in better hands than ever before.

The movie is set in Los Angeles 30 years after the original Blade Runner and follows the story of an LAPD cop who "retires" replicants, though in a twist he is a replicant himself, albeit a new, obedient model.
The good bits: The movie definitely maintained the haunting, dystopian atmosphere of the first Blade Runner. Denis Villeneuve did a good job of keeping this universe consistent with the orignal Blade Runner universe. The movie was well-plotted with a nice plot twist. The acting was decent, although the actors were not called upon to display much range. It was a very serious movie with almost no humour to offer occasional relief.
The bad bits: Hollywood, MORE IS NOT BETTER. A running time of over two hours and forty minutes is just too long. If you can't tell your story in 100 minutes, you need to tighten it up. The "atmosphere" scenes without dialogue were interminable and most could have been cut with little loss. Most of the fight scenes could have been cut or shortened.
The movie was very violent. I realize the original was too, but somehow the violence in Blade Runner 2049 disturbed me more. It was way more graphic. Also, after a while, it got ridiculous: The main character was wounded in ways that would kill a normal person seven times over, yet he just kept bouncing back. The same goes for the Bad Guy (or Bad Gal in this case.)
What truly irritated me about this movie, though, was the depiction of women. None of the characters was very well developed, but the female ones in particular were one-dimensional. They weren't even real people; they were tropes. You had the "ruthless evil bitch", the "angelic mother who sacrificed all" and of course tons of women as disposable sex toys. There was one scene in particular that I found very disturbing. The main character K has a fantasy hologram girlfriend. She (?) somehow invites a prostitute up to the apartment and sort of overlays her body so K can have sex with a real woman while it looks like he's having sex with his hologram. I found the idea of negating a real woman and turning her into some sort of fantasy very creepy.
There's also lots of gratuitous female nudity that has nothing to do with the story, but is just thrown in there. Some would argue that it helps set the atmosphere, but I think it was just to titillate. There's a small bit of male nudity, but it's presented clinically as replicants under construction and not erotically.
Given that Denis Villeneuve directed the excellent and sensitive movie "Arrival", I was all the more disappointed by Blade Runner 2049.
My overall score: 2.5 stars out of 5.

Following the original Blade Runner is not just following a film, but an odyssey of sight, sound and lore. Something that is at times, missing from BR2049.

In Blade Runner 2049, We're left with a visually stunning film with a great story line, and even some clever pre-movie vignettes, yet lost was the continuation of using music and sound design in almost every scene along with compelling characters set in the world we know as Los Angeles.

In the original Blade Runner, many scenes and characters had their own themes... just watch the original Blade Runner and you'll see and hear that. There are also a LOT of soundtracks for Blade Runner out there! Well, I left BR2049 feeling uninterested in obtaining it's soundtrack and that's saying a lot. All I heard was a rehash of the main theme in various forms: Long drawn out power chords, Inception type "BLAAAATTTTS" and an almost shameful reuse of music from the first film, almost needle dropped in here and there. It felt like the film didn't really know how to properly create an homage to Vangelis's score and what was done, as powerful as it was at times, simply sounded disconnected and rushed in places. No one really had a theme. No music stood out as original. Sad Face but true.

There were also quite a few questions raised but left unanswered. When I found our Jared Leto's character was blind only because Jared thought it would be 'cool', I felt this sort of explained why the film had so many character developmental holes in it. There simply was no true attention to character detail as there was in the first film. The first film had perfect pacing, busy streets, everything made sense. This film felt stark and narrow minded in it's specific, albeit riveting plot. There were also some continuity issues in that Los Angeles is apparently still the Atari driven, holographic mega-opolis, yet we hardly get to really see any of it! It's like The Omega Man except for what, one or two scenes with what felt like 1/4 of the extras the original film had and in scenes that felt shot in a day or two. I suspect this had to do with shooting in Hungary and not having access to utilizing potential shooting locations or extras... perhaps too expensive this day and age to pull off? It just felt like I remember more CG and less 'set design'. Missing was the iconic Dragon Neon too or at least I didn't see it.

In the end, the story was brilliant. I just felt it lacked understanding of the first film's vibe and lore. It also felt like there was no pre-screening and discussion of before it's release, leaving it feeling neutered... 

One thing that bothered me was K's final scene. Again, we're treated to Tears in Rain which was fine, but once again it seemed like if you're going to do that, then where was K's tears? If you watched the film, you no doubt caught on to something about the Nexus8 series and their 'tears'... K should of shed a tear in the snow which should of froze on his face among the other falling snow flakes! Why did this not happen? It almost felt like someone forgot to add this in post as THAT would of been the #2 riveting reveal which would of been a double whammy on it's own plot 'twist' revealed earlier. It also would of setup much more fodder in pushing for a #3. Maybe that was the point. K didn't cry - yet because the film lacked so many answers, we're left not caring why or understanding why, plus why the mixed message with using Tears in Rain then? The film never got deep enough to really explain this in the first place.

'Blade Runner 2049' comes 35 years after the original - and you have to ask, "why?" Directed by Villeneuve ('Arrival') and only produced by Ridley Scott (why is he involved in his own sequel, but not directing?), it doesn't even attempt to answer the main question of the first film - is Deckard (Ford) a replicant? Why is it always raining? Why do Ford & Leto only have a total of about four scenes between them? Why does it go for over 2 & a half hours?

There is some plot, with K (Gosling) being a replicant Blade Runner, tasked by Joshi (Wright) to track down runaway replicants, which leads to uncovering a mystery surrounding Deckard & Rachael. It takes 100min for Ford to even appear. In the meantime, Hans Zimmer tries to recreate the original's iconic score, but not as synth-y and sometimes a bit too overwrought. There's a lot of K interacting with Joi (de Armas), his 'Her'-like holographic maid. Most of this is handled quite well, with the CGI of Joi interacting with the light and her surroundings done excellently. But, it doesn't help move the film along at all.

There is occasional bits of action/violence, mostly thanks to Luv (Hoeks), but not enough to sustain the first two hours, with the clues slowly unravelling and not much excitement. It does pick up in the final 45min and has a passable ending, but mostly I'm left with the feeling of "it looks cool, but why do I care?" Good to see heaps more of the flying cars, and like 'Star Wars', everything looks realistic and "lived-in", but most of the concepts have now been explored better by 'Terminator' and 'Mad Max'.
It's so fluffy I just want to hug it and console myself.

It can be hard to follow up films that prove to be icons in their genre and continue the legacy they built on, especially 35 years after the original. "Blade Runner 2049" manages to do just that under the direction of Dennis Villeneuve.

Headlined by Ryan Gosling as LAPD Officer K, a blade runner, this film continues the journey of the original, reprising some film and voices originally used, as well as that films lead actor, Harrison Ford, as Officer Rick Deckard. Officer K stumbles upon a mystery of the past, something that could change the relationship or humans and replicants, and embarks on a journey of world-changing discovery, leading to his run-in with Deckard. Jared Leto masterfully plays Niander Wallace, a visionary and genius, who has taken over the defunct Tyrell Corp, creators of the original replicants who are hunted down by the blade runners. The blade runners were told to have been shut down for years, with this dystopian world having gone through a worldwide blackout, damaging many memory drives of the past, and an incredible famine.  Wallace finds ways to stop the blackout and famine, leading him and his ego to the top. This allows him to take over for Tyrell Corp, which had gone defunct, and build his new obeying replicants, whom he calls "angels." Ana de Armas, as Joi, an AI holographic girlfriend of Officer K, and Sylvia Hoeks as Luv, Wallace right-hand and also a replicant, add to the powerful characters of this film.

Yet, what makes this film on par with what the original brought to the table, is the entire cinematic experience we are given. Roger Deakins puts together one of the most visually stunning films I have seen in a long time. The visuals of this dystopian future are as spot on as I could imagine, color in the right places and not in others. The memory-making scene is a simple yet visually dramatic production and the radioactive wasteland is perfectly captured. I can't say enough of how visually stunning of a film it is. This is all enhanced by the dramatic score created by Benjamin Wallfisch and Hans Zimmer. I don't know exactly how to describe it, but the sensations created by notes magnifies the experience in a thrilling way that perfectly hits. It is spot on in how it plays back to the original. 
I can't say enough about how much I enjoyed this film. It hits all the points you are looking for, acting, sound, visuals, and story, and further enhances the original film. What a shockingly great surprise this was. It may even be better than the original.

I can only liken the experience of watching this movie to staring at a well-constructed building. I can appreciate the skill and artistry that went into constructing it. I can marvel at how intricate the design choices are that went into making it. I can admire it as something beautiful, grand and impressive, and there's a joy in exploring its intricacies and making surprising discoveries.

But a building, no matter how finely-made, can make me cry. Or laugh. Or scream, or gasp, or feel anything other than completely dispassionate and impersonal admiration for its construction.

The movie spends time being subtle and mysterious (a *lot* of time, considering it's nearly 3 hours long), but it doesn't bother providing genuine emotional connections between characters or to its audience, and seems to have no interest in doing so. It literally goes out of its way to damper the prospect of emotional connection of its central romance, then expects the audience to care about that romance's success or dissolution.

Being as vague as I can about the story (I learned it from watching you, Blade Runner 2049), the entire plot hinges on a broad statement that a character makes suggesting how dire the stakes are, but the movie does nothing to show that this statement is true. The film's bad guy pursues a course of action that, so far as I can tell, would put him out of business if successful, and is thus motivation-less. In the resolution of a mystery, we discover that a character chose an action that would provide an effective red herring, rather than him taking the rather obvious action that would be simpler and more effectively cover the mystery he's trying to hide.

It's a showcase for some magnificent cinematography. The performances are top-notch. The score is hypnotic. I've been thinking about the movie for a week, and I may even watch it again at some point, because it is that dense, and worthy of analysis.

But at no point did I feel emotionally connected. Much like my feelings towards the movie "Primer," I'm glad I watched it, and I appreciate its accomplishments. But I can't say I liked it.

Blade Runner 2049 is the sequel to the 1982 film, Blade Runner. It stars Ryan Gosling as Blade Runner agent K; as well as Harrison Ford, who reprises his role as Rick Deckard. 

To start off, I found the first Blade Runner to be an incredibly interesting exploration of an Earth far in advance in technology but, chronologically speaking, more or less set a few years from now. The film is slick and oozes an awesome, seductive, vision of the future that draws audiences in. The cyber-punk music and neo-noir style is something to admire. But, while its aesthetics are alluring in nature, the story of Blade Runner showcases a very downtrodden Los Angeles - the glamour and fame of A-list celebrities is clearly vacant, the fake facade of the American smile is washed away to reveal a depressing atmosphere, dripping with the threat of a gang, or, perhaps more of a worry, a replicant. A replicant is a biorobotic android who looks exactly like a normal human, with only a few signs of difference. 

To cut a fantastic story short, Deckard (Ford) is tasked with hunting down the remnants of a rebellious replicant crew, all due to be 'retired' (assassinated). However, he falls in love with a replicant, which is crucial to the main point of the film. What is humanity? What are the parameters that determine human from everything else? An idea further explored in Blade Runner 2049.

THE TECHNICAL ELEMENTS:
If I was asked to come up with one element of Blade Runner 2049 that really stuck out to me, I would mention the music. Music can create and define the personality of a film, it can shape and change the way we, as an audience, experience a certain scene. The long synthetic drones throughout the film are incredibly spine-tingling. It is important to note that the original Blade Runner also featured the same style of music. This was important to me, this was important to the success of this film. The music is used expertly, it adds a certain gravitas to the climax. However, most importantly for me, is its presence throughout the quiet moments of the film. The music can be harsh and sharp, but in the film's downtime, the quiet synth hum offers a calming sensation. 

The scenery, location, set-design is fantastic. From the large Egyptian-inspired Corporate pyramids to the crowded and compact city, Blade Runner's world tells a story through its aesthetics. There is a juxtaposition between the incredibly wealthy and the incredibly poor; there is seemingly more life, but more importantly, humanity, in the bereft in comparison to the wealthy, almost alien corporate beings. 

Both films seem to have a strange fetish for rain, it is almost a trademark element of the Blade Runner series. Personally, I believe that the rain is not only to set the tone of a neo-noir, but it is to also convey the idea that, like the sheer number of people living in the city dwellings add a certain pressure to oneself. And, like rain which dampens and soils your clothing until every fibre of your body is soaking and you feel oddly violated, the idea of a 'personal bubble' does not exist. In this, we empathise with these characters, we see people trying to come to terms with a harsh world in which all are mere lambs in comparison to the potential grasp of power that the corporations have. 

The film's excellence is not only contained within the confines of its cinematography; the acting within Blade Runner 2049 is flawless. Ryan Gosling was a perfect choice to play an initially emotionally-vacant officer to a battered and bruised sobbing mess by the end. The range on Gosling is astounding and when he felt pain, I did too. Harrison Ford returns as Deckard and he really impressed me and showed that he still had the ability to conjure up the emotional wherewithal to empathise and understand the emotional trauma that he has had to endure over the period of 30 years (the first film being set in 2019). There is one point in the film when K (Gosling) discovers a key clue to the finding of the child which is greatly executed through Gosling's warped teary-eyed face and the loud drone of the synthetic music, during this scene is when I decided that this would be one of my favourite films, the climax of the film decided for me that Blade Runner 2049 should be my tip-top favourite film of all time.   

THE STORY SUMMARISED *SPOILERS*:
Blade Runner 2049 follows LAPD Blade Runner K (Gosling), a replicant tasked with taking out older 'rogue' replicants. After retiring one replicant, K comes across an interesting find, which leads him on a mission to find the child of Rick Deckard and Rachel (the replicant Deckard fell in love with from the first film). 

Meanwhile, the disturbing Niander Wallace (Jared Leto) sends his enforcer Luv (Sylvia Hoeks) to tail K, with the aim of capturing the miracle child. Wallace being the head of an organisation that mirrors the Tyrell Corporation of the first film. Wallace has a God complex and believes that his replicants are angels that he wishes to force onto the world in their millions. 

The film's climax ends with an incredible fight between K and Luv. Watching the fight I found myself slowly leaning forward, becoming more and more entranced by the magnificence on the screen. The fight ends with K killing Luv and sending Deckard to his child. Having been mortally wounded in battle, K lays back, looks at the sky, and dies, knowing that his purpose is done. Deckard meets his child and the credits roll

CONCLUSION:
My summary of the plot does the film no justice at all and I thoroughly recommend it to anyone even remotely interested in seeing the film. To me, this film is my favourite; something about it cut deep into me and touched my very soul. Thank you, Denis Villeneuve, thank you Hampton Fancher and Michael Green, and, perhaps most importantly of all, thank you, Ridley Scott.

It is official, Blade Runner 2049 is an astounding triumph on multiple levels, it succeeds in crafting a sequel that builds upon its predecessor's story, and also stands on its own as a phenomenal modern sci-fi masterpiece. One of the greatest modern directors in Denis Villeneuve has created an immaculate film with a story that will render you speechless, characters that command your full attention, and filmmaking achievements that will go down in history. The main plot itself is a major spoiler which means you get a very vague synopsis that doesn't tell you much more than what the trailer does. The film follows K (Ryan Gosling), a blade runner who goes on a mission to unearth a secret that could change the world. As per usual, Roger Deakins' has teamed up with Villeneuve as the cinematographer and his work here is mesmerising, he captures this world in its best and worst light and either way it is beautiful. The score helmed by Hans Zimmer and Benjamin Wallfisch is electrifying and single handedly transports you into this world, as if you are living these events yourself. 

It is written by Michael Green and co-writer of the original Blade Runner Hampton Fancher and what they manage to create with the story here is more than I could have ever expected. It amazingly continues the story of this world and its inhabitants and acknowledges the fact that a lot has changed since we last saw it, as the original film is set 30 years prior to these events. But at the same time it is a story that newcomers to the universe can easily get sucked into with the induction of characters such as K and Jared Leto's Niander Wallace. And what is fantastic about this is that it doesn't just continue the story for the sake of knowing "what happens next" it goes in certain directions to add to the events of the original in the same way the original story adds to these new events. It doesn't forget the events of the past, it acknowledges them and respects them. I cannot possibly go into the details or even the vague direction of the story due to it being shrouded in heavy spoilers but it goes in directions you don't expect and holds many surprises around every corner. I would say it is a very character centric story where the events that occur and every scene that you follow is crucial to understanding a character and developing their narrative arc. 

Ridley Scott's Blade Runner is a film that to this day is visually incredible with cinematography that has stood the test of time and represents this futuristic world in the most beautiful way possible. Now you bring in one of the greatest cinematographers to ever exist in Roger Deakins and what he achieves here is undeniably stunning and easily some of his best work. The way this world is represented through darkness and colour creates an atmosphere and a feel for this world that is familiar yet foreign, and futuristic yet very lived in. Every shot had me in awe of everything I was seeing, every cityscape and every baron wasteland no matter how busy or empty had a story to tell and I was drawn in to this world like no other. Meanwhile, Zimmer and Wallfisch's score is the perfect acquaintance to this stunning cinematography with every piece of wall pounding sci-fi magic transporting you into this world and completely clearing your mind of the real one. I constantly found myself lost in this amazing score that compliments the visuals incredibly and it is most definitely one of my all time favourites. 

As far as the performances go, everyone involved brings their A-game, especially Ryan Gosling who commands the screen for the majority of the runtime and straight up never breaks character for a second. Not that this film needs carrying but Ryan owns every scene he is in and brings so much raw power and emotion to his character through the subtleties of his performance alone. Harrison Ford very much returns as the replicant(?) ex-blade runner Rick Deckard and where things have obviously changed in the 30 years he's been existing he still retains many of the personality traits that made Deckard... Deckard. He definitely doesn't phone it in and is compelling as this character who has now seen a lot of shit. But aside from Ford and Gosling the biggest standout of the film and quite possibly my favourite character is Jared Leto's Niander Wallace. Wallace is more or less the new Eldon Tyrell, the man at the head of the new corporation in charge of building replicants and he is such a mysterious and intriguing character I wanted to see more of him. Leto's portrayal of this character is brilliant, he is very creepy and unsettling yet I found myself loving him for his strong willed mindset and importance within this world. There are a number of other strongly compelling roles that I won't go into for various reasons, most of which are to withhold spoilers. 

So in the end there is no doubting the fact that this is a definitive masterpiece, there is not a single second of this film i didn't love and it could very well become one of my favourite movies of all time. The cinematography, score, story, characters, and performances are all so well executed and it is all wrapped up tied with a nice little bow by Denis Villeneuve who continues to prove why he is one of greatest directors working today. Now, do you need to have seen the original film to understand and appreciate this story??? Technically no, you don't, but I would implore you to do so before checking out this movie in order to get the most out of it. I would also definitely check out the three shorts that were released in the lead up to this film as they bridge the gap between the original and this sequel and give you a greater understanding of why the world is the way it is in 2049.

A perfect continuation of the previous film, Blade Runner 2049 masterfully recreates the world of Blade Runner while remaining a very unique and special stand-alone film. In Blade Runner 2049, the question of what makes us humanly persists; the replicants are more advanced and humanistic than ever before, helping make one replicant's journey to discover a purpose or earn a soul as deeply personal as Roy's was in the original. Expanding upon the themes of its predecessor, Blade Runner 2049 also examines different interpretations of love and what the future may behold. All of the different perspectives and ideas that get tossed around in the movie help it to be a thought-provoking experience and go beyond being entertainment. 
When it was first announced that Denis Villeneuve (Arrival, Sicario) was to be the director, I knew the film was in safe hands. Villeneuve, paired with cinematographer Roger Deakins (Sicario, Skyfall), have created one of the best visual experiences in a movie to date, effectively utilizing today's modern technology to take what the first Blade Runner did and make it even better. The cinematography is the best I've seen all year; there are so many shots where I was just sitting there admiring what was on screen, thinking, "wow, that's awesome". There were several different interesting locations in the film and so many cool set designs, which lead to a variety of color grades and lighting. While keeping the darkness and aesthetic of the original, Villeneuve adds his own flair and direction, making the film from start to finish a stylish piece; the future that has been made is wondrous yet not too far-fetched. The animation work and CGI in the film are also stupendous, whether it be a flying car or a hologram, everything looks so real. 
Ryan Gosling plays the lead, Officer K, a blade runner like Deckard was, who's good at his job and doesn't say much. Gosling excellently captures the held-back emotion that his character experiences while working on his investigation and slowly starts to let out that emotion as the film progresses. There is one scene in particular where he discovers something big relative to the plot and Gosling's talents are once again put on full display, exhibiting an array of emotions such as anger, fear, and disbelief all in a brief few-second period. Harrison Ford reprises his famous role as Rick Deckard, and while onscreen less than initially expected, Ford is able to craft a new, wisened form of Deckard that adds a whole new layer to the film. Jared Leto plays Niander Wallace, the new Tyrell of sorts, and while he also has less screen time than expected, Leto does what he does best, create an intriguing, complex character. Although some may see Leto's character as the antagonist, his character is more so just morally ambiguous and unpredictable. In this role, Leto flashes disdain and creepiness, while remaining ambiguous enough that you never fully come to understand his character's true intentions, making it hard to label him as something so simple as a bad guy; sorry Leto haters, but he is here to stay. Ana De Armas plays Gosling's love interest in the film, Joi, and brings to the table a heartfelt performance and adds depth and intrigue to a character who is nothing more than an artificial program. De Armas makes you believe that her character is a real person and you feel sympathetic for Joi even though you know there are probably thousands of her out there. The chemistry between Gosling and De Armas is great, as they produce a fantastical romance that is touching to watch while technically not real and is one of the many interesting concepts presented that may or may not occur in the future.  Slyvia Hoeks plays Luv, Niander Wallace's right-hand woman, and is intimidating and intense, specifically during the latter half of the movie. Mackenzie Davis, Robin Wright, and Dave Bautista also add to the many different perspectives and characters we see in the film with their own stories, helping the film truly feel like the grand Sci-Fi opera it is. 
	In Blade Runner 2049, even the smaller things make a big difference. The futuristic costume designs that the different characters wear (besides Deckard who just wears a T-shirt) are neat takes on what future fashion will look like, the twists and turns of the story keep the audience engaged and captivated, and the few fight scenes we get are intense, practical, and hard-hitting. Hans Zimmer and Benjamin Wallfisch's soundtrack stays close to Vangelis' while retaining its own unique style, both ethereal and powerful. 
	Blade Runner 2049 will most certainly not be for everyone, as its two hours and forty-four-minute runtime can be taxing and the pacing of the film is much more like the tortoise than the hare (although remember, the tortoise ends up beating the hare). The plot won't appeal to everyone either. I recommend watching the original Blade Runner beforehand, preferably the final cut, just to get a taste of what you'll be seeing if you do plan on seeing the new one; receiving context never hurt anybody either. Blade Runner 2049 is a sequel but is also its own story, its own journey, and masterfully expands upon the concepts and features that made the original good; the movie even ends in a way so the potential of a third part is real, assuming the bomb at the box office fixes itself. Blade Runner 2049 is quite possibly the best movie I've seen in 2017, and most certainly will not be lost in time, like tears in the rain.

More Human Than Human or Does An Androids Dream Of Being A Real Boy

Director Denis Villeneuve and cinematographer Roger Deakins paint a stunningly vivid depiction of a desolate, dystopian world where humanity has lost its humanity, its soul and individuality had been erased or lost.

While at the same time; mankind's children and possibly its successors the enslaved biosynthetic lifeforms known as Replicants seek to rise above their programming and achieve what mankind has lost. Indeed, what does it mean to be human?

Ryan Gosling's K wants nothing more than to achieve individuality and rise above his systematic and mundane tasks of "maintaining order" for a dying society.

On the opposite side, Harrison Ford's Deckard is a man who chose to abandon humanity in order to protect what's most important to him. His actions and sacrifices are purely dictated by mankinds' greatest imperative; LOVE. Surrendering his humanity in order to protect that which he loves and cherishes most.

These two characters paint a stimulating picture of what it means to be human. Replicants manufactured to simulate human consciousness and yet seem to have no true soul; while humans have souls but they've lost their humanity and commit unspeakable acts for the "greater good." 

What does it mean to be human? The film never answers this question directly, instead leaving the viewer to answer this conundrum for themselves as plot points come and go and the ambiguity gives a distinct richness to the film.

The film's 2 hour and 43 minutes run time offers an extensive exploration of the frightfully beautiful world that is "Blade Runner 2049". What does it mean to be More Human Than Human! It's a beautiful existential crisis.

2049 is extremely ambitious in what it does and really swings for the fences trying to capture that cinema magic like the original but man it was a huge miss for me.  There will be some savants that truly love what they see but I can earnestly say it is not for everyone.

At its very core the film does not offer much, the meat and bones of it are dressed up and packaged beautifully but it doesn't make up for the lack of content.  The pacing of the nearly 3 hour film felt very unnecessary and unforgivable at times.  

I've seen the original 3 times and they manage to deliver a great sci-fi thought provoking adventure while delivering serious themes throughout.  They also introduced elements very subtly & ambiguously which is one of the main driving forces that label it a cult classic.  

Sadly, this sequel does the exact opposite of that in every way possible.  You're not just spoon fed but force fed symbolism and metaphors that really aren't that thought provoking at all in a constant and blaring fashion.  It makes for a lot of artistic "ooohhs" and "aaahhhs" but leaves out the main elements of an enjoyable film.

There was a serious lack of memorable characters & grand scenes which made it very anticlimactic.  The whole time I was waiting for a big reveal and it never came...the whole audience in the theatre looked around at the end with a "that's it?" reaction.

Overall I give it a  heartbreaking 6/10.  I walked away thinking that critics were paid or just too enamored by the artistic theatrics.  It would take a lot for me to be able to watch this again but I'd be more than happy to see the original one more time right away. In the majority of films I watch, weather they are good or not, I have a moment where I wonder how much longer is left; I didn't even think about how long this movie was until the end credits finished and the lights came on in the theater. The story is a tad slow, but there is so much happening on screen to observe at any time that there is never a moment of boredom. Ryan Gosling and Harrison Ford are amazing but so is every single other performance from every single other character. Blade Runner 2049 is very very stylistically different than the original which allows it to stand on it's own as a real film, as opposed to a sequel. The main aspect that blew my opinion of this movie from being great to being a masterpiece is the cinematography, lighting, and special effects. The settings, the rooms, the contrasting lighting, and the special effects that establish a majority of the world we see are all done so unbelievably well that it is almost impossible to describe without showing the entire movie itself. My point is: see this movie!

What makes you a human? There is plenty of these type of questions that Blade Runner 2049 always refers back too in this science fiction film that is very much impressive. And I ll admit this, better than the original movie which may shock to all since the first was a cult hit of a movie. I feel like all the credit has to go to director Denis Villeneuve in making a compelling, visually done film. Blade Runner 2049 may not please every one in the audience and it sure will divide the audience either they enjoy it or find it boring. Lets get this straight out in the open. Blade Runner is not the typical Hollywood science fiction action movie were it is loaded with big action set pieces throughout. I ll also admit, this film could have used a little more action but otherwise the movie does well in its storytelling, impressive visuals, and a stunning direction. 

I do not want to give too much away about the plot. The less you know the better the movie will be. I ll just give the basic plot outline of a blade runner named K (Ryan Gosling) who hunts down replicants (bioengineered humans) who have been defective. Well on his first case of hunting a replicant, he unearths something that will get the attention from a corporation led by Wallace (Jared Leto) who is trying to perfect a great replicant. And K will need the help of a former blade runner Deckard (Harrison Ford) in order to find answers about what he has discovered that can change everything they once knew. 

The storytelling in this film is what makes it great. It is slow moving in a good way. It does leave you wanting to explore more about the dystopian future. The film spends its time in a futuristic Los Angeles, were its gloomy and flashy with its holograms. Then, K travels to San Diego, were it is a complete wasteland. Where L.A. dumps there massive loads of trash, which literally looks like a huge city of a junkyard. Also, the landscapes of Las Vegas, were it is orange and gloomy from the radioactive. These sequences of different areas does want you to explore more about. Also, K interpersonal relationship with his A.I. device that he carries with him that brings up a hologram of a young woman (Ana de Armas) who can keep him company emotionally or physically. There is plenty of details in the story that the film does take its time with its length. But it never gets boring. 

The visual effects are top notch impressive. Like I mentioned above about the landscapes to its neo noir lighting from the city. And to even make everything better is the music score by Hans Zimmer and Benjamin Wallfisch. Bringing back the original score theme and adding a few changes does give you that nostalgia feeling when seeing the score volume loud and seeing every shot with the camera done great as it captures the visual sets and effects. 

Director Denis Villeneuve (known for Prisoners, Sicario, and Arrival) if you seen those films. You should know he builds suspense, characters, and overachieves in trying to capture the best shot visually. And a lot of talking throughout the movie. Well the same goes for Blade Runner. He is all about storytelling and respecting the original by exploring further with its plot. He is starting to become one of my favorite directors that can always capture a tone and build its suspense. Sure, my one small issue with the film is it does lack in some action sequences. You get some small brief fight scenes and shooting sequence. And than a flying car chase in the climax. But I only wish there was a bit more to the action. 

Otherwise, Blade Runner 2049 is a good science fiction film. The direction and music score is great. The visuals are amazing and hard to take eyes off the screen. Ryan Gosling and the cast ensemble were good. The storytelling is slow moving but works great at being an artistic film than a typical action blockbuster. 

I rate the film 4 out of 5 stars. I recommend to see it on the big screen for its impressive music score and visuals of a dystopian future and plot. If you enjoy an artistic science fiction movie or loved the original than this will be a film for you.
